"1984 was written in 1949 during the Cold War and the great fear of the communist invasion. It was rumored that communist spies were living amongst our society and threatened our very way of life. 1984 displays a powerful warning of what fear can lead to. This novel proves to maintain its relevancy even in today’s society, as we fear constant government surveillance under the guise of fighting the war on terror. The novel is not for children as it depicts scenes of torture. George Orwell’s 1984 has become the epitome of a dystopian society.George Orwell’s classic 1984 centers on the totalitarian control of Oceania. Citizens of Oceania live under constant surveillance from the “telescreens” and microphones placed everywhere from their house to place of work. Any facial expression that might show a feeling of distaste towards the “Party” in control will result in arrest, interrogation, and ultimately execution by the “Thought Police.” Even the children are taught espionage and to betray their parents at any sign of dissent from the “Party.” Individuality has been completely eradicated because any perceived eccentricity means certain death.The “Party” has complete control over the history that is presented to its citizens. They use this control to create the image of an infallible presence. Any contradiction to their word will be rewritten to portray the party in the correct manner. Because of the complete control that the “Party” has over its citizens, anything they say instantly becomes fact. The “Party” tells people that 2+2=5 and they unquestionably accept it as the truth. The “Party” seeks complete control over its citizen’s thoughts and even goes so far as to attempt to eradicate the orgasmOceania is constantly at war with either Eurasia or Eastasia and changes throughout the novel. When the enemy changes, the history books are rewritten so that Oceania is always at war with the one enemy. This constant state of war is used to keep the citizens of Oceania in fear of the outside world. Public executions of captured enemy combatants are to dehumanize the enemy and show that only “Party” members are human.The protagonist, Winston Smith, lives with distaste of the “Party”. After engaging in an unauthorized affair with Julia, the two of them seek out the rumored resistance to the “Party”. This resistance proves to be futile as they are both arrested by the “Thought Police” very quickly. After months of torture, Winston completely conforms and accepts that 2+2=5 and that he loves Big Brother."

"(Spoilers) I know this is a classic and I am all about the classics--moniker Classic Lit Fan--but I can't recommend this novel.  I'm a big fan of Orwell's Animal Farm and I understand that this one is supposed to be much darker but the middle part of this story is just ridiculous.  Part One is what most people know as 1984.  In it you have Big Brother watching everything and rewriting history as well as the future and most of the well known quotes come from this section.  If you just stopped there.... Part 2 is mostly the married main character, Winston Smith and his unauthorized ""girlfriend"" Julia sneaking around committing adultery and proclaiming they will never betray each other.  Part 3 is physical torture, psychological torture and more torture.  It is very disturbing even though not exactly what you would call graphic. And all this torture is used just to make Winston confess to all kinds of crimes he did and didn't commit, to leave him a shell of a man, and in a weirdly twisted way end up loving Big Brother. I get that Orwell is warning against totalitarian governments and the extreme measures they use to gain and keep total control over the minds and bodies of their subjects, but the story does not make you root for Winston and his ideas of how things should be. Instead of making you want to fight for what is right it makes you wish for total annihilation to hurry up and come."
"Psychopaths, and the insane control the ruling party of the government while monitoring the lives of ordinary party members. Any sign of rebellion such as a simple look or thought could place the person under arrest. The punishment could be a bullet to the head, vaporization, or tortured into complete submission. The party leaders tell members what they should believe even if 2 + 2 = 5. They also rewrite history to fit their need, redefine words, and mislead with contradictory news broadcasts.Whatever the party says is true and members must agree even if they know that it isn't true. Non-members of the party, namely the working class, are not bothered as they are considered too simple to grasp anything beyond basic wants and desires. It’s the intelligent party members who pose a threat and those are kept under close watch with little to no chance of privacy.Hence the term, Big Brother is watching. Follow the life of Winston Smith, a party member, as he seeks to join the elusive and rebellious group ,known as The Brotherhood , to fight against big brother. Does he succeed or fail? Live or die? The end might surprise. A character driven story that often slows down with excessive narration explaining various terms and politics. Opinions and ideas deduced from the novel are many and varied but to me this is the horror version of ""Alice in Wonderland.""""How puzzling all these changes are! I'm never sure what I'm going to be from one minute to another.""Lewis Carroll, Alice's Adventure in Wonderland Kindle Ed. page 28""But I don't want to go among mad people,"" Alice remarked. ""Oh, you can't help that."" said the cat: ""we're all mad here. I'm mad. You're mad.""Lewis Carroll, Alice's Adventure in Wonderland Kindle ed. page 32Recommend to readers who enjoy dystopian science fiction."
"I remember this being an assigned reading book in my junior year of high school. I was never one to like to be told what to do, so had I picked this book out on my own I probably would have really enjoyed it from the start as it falls in direct line with the style of writing that I enjoy, but making it required made it distasteful to me. However I read the book because I always completed my assignments whether I wanted to or not, but once I got through about two thirds of the way through with the book, I read three simple lines that made the hair on the back of my neck stand on end.It's in the tenth chapter of the second part where Winston and Julia have just finished making love in their secret apartment. I did not find anything interesting in this scene because to me it was just like two teenagers sneaking around behind their parent's back. This is something that was the topic of conversation at every table in the cafeteria no matter the clique of kids the table happened to occupy. But then there were these words:""'We are the dead.' he said.'We are the dead,' echoed Julia dutifully.You are the dead.' said an iron voice behind them.""I vividly remember sitting back down on the edge of my bed and letting out a ""Whoa"" and suddenly becoming very interested in the book. I then chuckled at the next like that said ""Winston's entrails seemed to have turned to ice."" The combination of the hilarity of frozen entrails and the creepy iron voice telling them they were dead from behind a picture frame demanded of me to start the book over.While the beginning seemed to lag to me, and there is a lot of repetition about policy and the monotony of life, I was really jarred that this very well could be a depiction of the types of censorship we could experience in the future. And the just weeks ago it feels like Big Brother materialized from the pages of Orwell's book and into the mainstream media in the form of the new Facebook messenger. I am sure apps like this have existed since all of our technology has begun to advance, but this one has been chosen as the poster child. Maybe Big Brother has decided it is time to start watching us, or maybe still, just like with Winston and Julia, Big Brother has been watching all along, he was just always hiding underneath the other side of our screen.Pretty crazy that they chose to have the voice come out from behind a screen isn't it? Since it seems we all live our lives in front of or hid behind screens at all times these days. Just something to think about.This book changed the idea of forward creativity for me, and without it I don't think I would be as intrigued in the development of new creative frontiers as I am for having read this. 1984 very easily may have been what started it all for me, and I am so very grateful."

"Reviewed By: Caleb JiangISBN-10: 0451524934ISBN-13: 978-0451524935Number of Pages: 328 pages  1984 is a dystopian style book that was the first of its kind. Written in a time right after the atomic bombing of Nagasaki and Hiroshima in Japan, this is Orwell's ingenious take on the kind of country he thought The Soviet Union was. In most ways, he was right. The book 1984 and The Soviet Union both have a totalitarian government. There are police that will torture you and kill you if you think rebellious thoughts or do rebellious things.  There is rations on everything and the only thing the television ever shows is pro-government propaganda. So, what's unique about 1984? Is it just a book describing life in The Soviet Union? Well, not exactly. 1984 seems much more futuristic with ""telescreens"" that are constantly monitering your activities in your home. The government also not only shoves a lot of propaganda in your face, but also brainwashes its citizens. It forces its citizens to ""doublethink"". Doublethink is when you think that two completely opposite things are the same. For example, The Ministry of Truth alters history with a bunch of lies and The Ministry of Plenty gives smaller rations each day. However, with doublethink, if you received 1 gallon of water yesterday from the Ministry of Plenty and only 1/2 Gallons today, you will think that this is a increased amount of water because the Ministry told you so. You need to be able to doublethink to understand doublethink. Your memory will literally be nonexistant in Oceania, the country where this all takes place. At least, that's the goal of The Party, the government of Oceania. In my opinion, this novel provides a sort of insight into what our government will turn into is the CIA keeps on spying on every part of our daily lives. The novel details how a governing body can completely turn you into a mindless, brainwashed slave. You, the reader takes the position of Winston Smith, a not yet brainwashed citizen that secretly hates The Party. There are plenty of surprises and plot twists throughout the novel makes everything you thought before different. This philosophical journey is slow in some parts, but it'll all be worth it in the end. If you want a book that you can't stop reading once you start it, this one is for you. One last thing, pretty much all of the book takes place in a time when Oceania changing their language from Standard English to Newspeak, a language with such limited vocabulary that it makes it impossible for rebellion to happen. There will be a bit of a learning curve as you learn a bunch of new words that never existed until now.This book is appropriate for ages 13+ or anyone looking for a classic for their high school essay in their English class."
I wish it was still mandatory reading for high school kids today. This is precisely where we are headed as a society unfortunately.

A classic tale well told.
"1984 was written in the 1940s by George Orwell. In the novel, Orwell pessimistically predicted the most bleak, depressing future possible given the frightening post-WWII political climate.The world of 1984 is controlled by totalitarian communist regimes. In the fictional mega-country of Oceania, this quasi-government is called ""The Party."" The goal of the Party is to subjugate individual human impulses, thoughts, and desires to the will of the whole. This is maintained by an endless series of rules, monitoring, and ceaseless propaganda.Winston, the protagonist, feels that life isn't as it should be, despite the endless propaganda. He finds small and large ways to rebel against the system without getting caught. But 1984 is far, far darker, bleaker, and more pessimistic than similar books in the genre, like Ayn Rand's Anthem or Lois Lowry's The Giver. Orwell doesn't allow any cliches in his book. Winston hates totalitarianism, but he is far from virtuous. And, without going into further detail--do not expect a happy ending.Orwell paints such a complete picture of a totalitarian triumph that the reader is left with little to no hope. 1984 is a cautionary tale, and Orwell was sending a clear message to society--""Don't let it get to this point."""

"The dystopian genre is easily one of my least favorite genres in literature. However, every genre, no matter how bad it is, does have its gem. 1984 is that gem. But it boggles my mind on why it is so good and lacking in cliche. Maybe it's because this book was written WAY before the dystopian boom caused by novels like The Hunger Games and Divergent. Maybe it's because it doesn't focus on sappy relationships. Maybe it's because they didn't force the evil government it created down our throats. But more likely, it is all of this combined. It holds barely any cliches. It does something original for both a modern audience and an audience for the people of 1949 (when this book was released). The relationship that is built up in this book doesn't take over the story and is treated more as a devise to smartly show the world's corruption more than to show the characters. If I were to say everything amazing about this book, I would be hear for hours. But I will keep this shorter and say that I can't recommend this book enough. Simply put, it's a masterpiece."

"I believe '1984' is standard reading for many high school/college English classes, but it wasn't in mine. I decided to read it on my own this summer, and boy am I glad I did.1984 tells the story of Winston Smith, a man who lives in THE totalitarian government, wants to fight back, and isn't entirely sure how. He is watched almost all the time, must be constantly on guard against showing dissent from the party, or else he will be disappeared. While he and similar characters aren't exactly brimming with personality, they don't need to be to make this book good.The greatest thing about this book is the government itself. A common saying in this book is [paraphrased] 'he who controls the past controls the future, and he who controls the present controls the past'. Orwell goes into detail on how to accomplish this, and delivers on all of the horror, both stated and unstated, that goes along with it. The even more classic line 'War is Peace' is brought up, and explained in such a way that I even found it plausible in a severely twisted sort of way. And the worst part? All of this misery, terror, and oppresion? It's entirely believable that it could happen to us. The government doesn't need any sci-fi tech to take absolute control, and they don't need it. Heck, North Korea is doing something similar right now!One minor thing I have to say I like is the prose. A lot the book I've read that are sixty years have a lot of archaic grammar and word choice. 1984 doesn't for the most part.I recommend this book to anyone interested in classic literature, second only to 'Catch-22' in my list of books you should read. So, you know, buy it."

"""Published in 1949, Orwell’s 1984 is a dystopian novel set in a tyrannical world. The Party and Big Brother, the Party leader accorded quasi-deity status, control all as part of an effective superstate with omnipresent government surveillance, manipulation of all citizens and continuous alterations of history to make whatever spoken to have always been and have happened. This is the world Winston Smith inhabits, a talented rewriter of history and part of the system, a world in which he harbours dangerous, nonconformist thoughts of individualism, truth, freedom and rebellion.There is so much this book covers – censorship, the power of the state over the individual, history and its recording, nationalism, surveillance, individualism and more. It does not skate over them, merely mentioning them but truly engages by making them an integral part of the world and Smith’s struggles. Because of this, I found the book quite dense and could only read it in small doses, having to frequently put it down to give my brain a chance to reflect and mentally refresh before willingly plunging in again."""
A  cautionary tale written in the mid twentieth century with lessons for today.Study the past and do not disregard the importance of mistakes therein. Cherish the family and your memories.

I'm not kidding-I think I cried 4 times reading this book. Now, the first time I read it was when I was in 8th grade. It was not required for any class-I simply wanted to read it. So I am not biased or anything because of a lame teacher forcing me to read this. I thoroughly enjoyed this book. Also, although I understood most of the topics featured here, I realized that I appreciated everything about the book much more when I was older. I begin comparing it to my own life, and relating to the characters. The text is also not hard to understand at all-it's not old English or anything. I would definitely recommend everyone to read this (Well, not everyone. It's more for mature audiences.)"

"Along with Yevgeny Zamyatin’s We (1924) and Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World (1932), George Orwell’s Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949) is the one of the most powerful and important dystopian novels every written, and unquestionably a work of science fiction thanks to its depiction of a future totalitarian regime that controls every aspect of its citizen’s mental and physical existence. It’s hard to imagine any educated person in the English-speaking world who hasn’t heard the terms Big Brother, doublethink, thoughtcrime, and Newspeak, even if they’re not sure exactly what they mean. It’s also likely that many readers were exposed to the book in high school English or Humanities classes, which is a good time to read any important book. I’d say this book has probably had a greater social and political impact than any other work of speculative fiction. Who, after reading it, could possibly see any merit whatsoever in a totalitarian government, even if it governs ostensibly for the good of its citizens?"

"This book hardly needs another review from anyone.  Published in 1946 it is very closely based on Orwell's views of Stalin and the Soviet Union of that time.  While it has been most quoted for its thoughts on doublespeak, doublethink and the phrases that War is Peace, Freedom is slavery, etc, the real thrust of the work is how to alter the consciousness of human beings to believe wholeheartedly in anything that the state proclaims as true.  In this sense, it is a work illustrating Althusser's concept of ""interpolation."" although Orwell writes before this theory is defined.  It is also closely based on Evgenij Zamyatin's work ""WE.""  It is worth reading, but gets very wordy and often boring."

"What a compelling read. Or I should say listen, since I did the audiobook. Where do I start? I'm still processing, I think.In some ways I wish I had read it since I don't feel like I really grasped some of the concepts like doublespeak right away. But by the end I think I got it.It just astounds me how prophetic so many things seem to be, especially when I'm at my most cynical. The differences between why young Julia breaks the rules vs. why Winston is breaking them, for instance. Big Brother could be the NSA, or heck, even Facebook. The reason for the ""war"", good God that rings true.When I look at the divide between classes in America, and the suppression of the lower classes, and being a struggling middle class member myself.... Not to mention the mind games the media plays. It all rings a warning bell.Oh yes, there is a lot to process on this book. I highly recommend it to anyone who has a desire to think about society and the way things can go horribly wrong. The damage that can be done by just going along with the status quo.In some ways 1984 is an outrageous exaggeration, but then when one looks at where we are today, the things that haven't come true are far more plausible given the things that HAVE come true--not precisely, but thematically.This is not a happy book. "Admittedly, and please bare this in mind, I don't excel at the exercise of placing myself within the timeframe and perspective that a book is written, especially when that timeframe is 20 years prior to my birth.With that said, the foresight that George Orwell had in forecasting some of the suppressive social and economic political strategies was absolutely mindblowing. In 1945, the book's publishing date, the political structure that he created was, I'd assume, stunningly innovative and trailblazing. However, due to a general familairity with today's current governmental landscapes, the amount of detail in his descriptions of the setting of 1984 can be a bit redundant and tiresome. 65 years ago, due to unfamilairity, it may have taken him 150 pages to effectively paint 1984's setting, whereas, today,it would only take 30 or 40. Variations of this particular backdrop have been recycled and repeated tirelessly throughout the years, and, nowadays, this type of framework can't represent the main plotline on it's own.In conclusion, whilst reading 1984, it's important to constantly reminding myself that it marked the birth of political futurology, where continuous and disapproved surveillance is an alarming weapon that seems destined for abuse by the world's most powerful people. I was constantly astonished by Orwell's scarily accurate foresight of our current world, and was satisfied to have finally experienced the novel that started it all."
"I’m still trying to grasp the concept of this new world order where everyone is brainwashed into hate and abstinence. Basically any sort of natural bond is being bred out of society into the hopes that one day there will be no more marriage, children will be taken away from their mothers at birth and the act of sex will be a repulsive, yet mandatory act that will take place once a year simple to repopulate the planet. In a way, this book reminded me of Suzanne Collin’s Hunger Games series with the government conspiracies leading the people like a flock of sheep. It was quite apparent to me after reading, where Collin's may have gotten her inspiration.The fact that children are being brainwashed at such a young age and can turn on their parents in an instant is unsettling. This new order wants as little thought as possible. They are attempting to rein in a society of people and treat them like mere machines.Basically this really could be happening today. The media lies to us about the reasons behind war and we believe it. But the actual cause is what it’s always been: the middle class attempting to debunk the upper class while the lower class remains ignorant to it all. There are a few things that really make you question your own beliefs. Every day, the media floods our TV’s giving us statistics, comparing things from last year to this year and who really validates it? We expect the news reporter to speak the truth but we do nothing ourselves to be vigilant about receiving the truth. We could easily turn into this party discussed in 1984. If you're big on conspiracy theories, you will love this book."

"This book gets greater by the year. Anyone who has trouble understanding what is going on in the world, maybe especially in the U.S., can use this novel almost as a guide book, a sort of decoder ring. Orwell said that he meant to portray an ersatz communist/Soviet regime, as a signpost for his contemporaries who didn't see clearly past the surface. As Winston Smith's yearnings and mistakes are so very universal, perhaps tyrants and their stooges are also universal. The ones portrayed here certainly make effective stand-ins for those we've inflicted upon ourselves in this decade. The NSA and Homeland Security are very well portrayed here, right down the line. I wish we were reacting to our overlords with better purpose than Winston mustered, but we're not even close."
"Orwell marvelously portrays a world where a totalitarian government controls the mind of its subjects by altering history and belittling the human belief in the ""self."" The author definitely leaves you wondering how truly important your own memories and thoughts are in the face of a government that can erase and control knowledge given to the general populace. In addition, the novel also makes you question how malleable the human mind is. In the face of enough torture, do we really succumb to thoughts that are against our own nature or feelings? Orwell reveals that our minds are more malleable than we would like to believe. I would recommend for anyone who liked reading Fahrenheit 451/ other dystopian novels."

"​In the book “1984”, George Orwell is writing to us about a dystopian society. George Orwell wrote the book in 1949 as a warning to the people about a controlling government. The book pretty much gives us an imaginary world that is controlled completely by police. For an example, there is what you call a “thought police”. These police control what the people think at all times. If you are caught thinking something about the future or recording what is happening in the world then you will be put on probation and eventually thrown in jail. One person that rebels against the society is Winston Smith. Winston is the main character in the novel. He searches for the truth longing to find out about the past. While trying to rebel he runs into a girl that is the same way as him. He would eventually have a love affair with her. They both get arrested by the thought police and taken to jail. While in jail, Winston is not abused physically, but mentally. The thought police’s main goal while he is in prison is to mentally wash his mind away. The society tries to brain wash everybody into thinking there is no past. They try to ruin people of their spiritual dignity. They make it seem like you cannot live on your own because you need to rely on the government for everything; there is no such thing as independence. Some people refer to this book as, “the history lesson you never had”. For me, this book made me realize how easily are government could control us if we do not stand up for our own rights as a whole. It is quite an eye opener. People insist that it can never happen, but think about North Korea. This book very well reminds me of them and how they have a communistic government."
I read this book a long time ago and just wanted to have it at hand.  Will read it again just as a reminder of all that was said and done.
"George Orwell’s, Nineteen Eighty Four, is a riveting novel describing one man’s rebellion from dystopian society. Winston, the protagonist, lives his habitually boring life in the hopes he will find a person whom shares his belief towards society. The society Winston lives in is run by the Party and ultimately “Big Brother”. The citizens are constantly monitored and taught to destroy individual thought. The details used by Orwell in describing the tactics of the Party to control society is not only knowledgeable, but also interesting. Orwell’s details create an altogether cohesive society with the main goal of total control. Winston’s role in society is a worker in the Party’s Ministry of Truth. This section of society deals with the history of society, which is constantly altered. Most citizens seem to be oblivious; however, Winston questions the validity of society’s historical truths. Orwell’s character development of Winston as analytical and doubtful, drive me to question the honorability of the society which I live in today. Later in the novel, Winston is faced with difficult decisions based on trust and intuition. These choices will either help or hurt him in his fight to change the corrupt society he lives in. Winston must trust his instincts in order to begin change in the society. Will Winston achieve his goal to reinvent the controlling society or will he die trying?"
"George Orwell does a fantastic job of creating a dystopian society in the novel, 1984. Orwell wrote the novel in 1984 and through the years it has remained true and classic, even in today’s society. We can see aspects of Orwell’s novel in media and entertainment. 1984 has influenced many books and movies, and even the infamous quote, “Big Brother is watching you.” The novel is set in 1984 in London in a nation of Oceania, and follows a man named Winston. Winston is not anyone special, no one in the society is special everyone is the same, except for Big Brother. Winston is living his life the way Big Brother wants him to he goes to work, he does his daily workouts, and he participates in hate time. Everything is going fine for Winston until Julia comes along. In the nation of Oceania love is illegal and Winston followed that rule then until was Julia who he fell in love with. That is when Winston’s mind started to open, he started to think for himself and he started to think maybe the society he lived in was not that great. Will Winston rebel against Big Brother? Will Julia follow him? Will others join Winston? Only time will tell."
"Nineteen eighty four, by George Orwell, is an intriguing novel. This book takes place in London ocienia. The year nineteen eighty four is a dystopian society where the main character, Winston, has trouble sometimes even remembering who he is. He is surrounded by things and people who confuse him. Yet he is not able to cry out or share his thoughts. He is told he is like everyone else. But does not believe it, he goes on extrodinary journeys trying to find his place in this world, which he knows is not who he is being forced to be. Throughout the novel Winston struggles to find who he really is and holds onto his memories that he has in order to rebel. This story brilliantly portrays all of the struggles in a dystopian society.  The main symbol of government authority is “big brother”. Big brother puts the people into place and makes them fear their authority. There are people designated to have certain jobs, even down to monitoring thoughts. These people are called “thought police”. They regulate thought and make sure the people of Oceania obey all laws.Winston goes through many struggles and becomes who he thought he would never be. I recommend this book, especially if you enjoy dystopian literature and a good read."
"Great book.  Kind of the seminal dystopian work.  Not sure how to describe it.  There's a guy, Winston, who's beginning to question the new order.  English socialism (IngSoc) has become the wool over the public's eyes so they may not see the truth about the ruling class and the constant state of ""war"".  Language is being dismantled and replaced by NewSpeak, which is the ultimate imposition of the totalitarian ruling class.  Conversation becomes relegated to terms such as ""ungood"", or doubleplusgood (excellent), sexcrime, goodest or gooder, etc.  The point is to remove thoughtfulness and meaning and to further implicate individuality as a subversive attempt against the ruling class.  Citizens are provided meager resources, such as stale rations of cigarettes or liberty vodka, tokens of the overarching govt that go nicely with the in house monitors through which Big Brother watches, at all times, even in the morning during mandatory mass calisthenics.  People are allowed anger once a week during the 2 minutes hate in which the enemy of the state is broadcast, as though he has stolen the airwaves and wishes to impart hope to an otherwise hopeless populace.  Winston meets a girl, goes with her places the upper class is not allowed, and bad things happen.  He mingles with the idiotic proles who are nothing if not helpless products of the new order, relegated to poverty and a war torn infrastructure.  Winston works in what could only be called the department of news, where he takes old newspaper articles and changes them to reflect the whims of the govt.  In effect, he changes the past, so that it reconciles with the new present that has been made up on an whim.This kind of story is all too familiar and often times it seems as though it is playing out right before our very eyes if in the most subtle ways.  Hence the term ""Orwellian"", which tends to be used to describe a dark and forboding future.  If you haven't read this book, you must."

"It’s easy to dismiss Orwell’s masterpiece as a quaint and dated dystopia, a banal nightmare of the future cobbled together in 1948 out of the dingy present and the recent past: the bombed out London of the novel looks like nothing so much as that city under the blitz. The scarcities and rationing, the war frenzy, the propaganda and paranoia required no imagination to describe. They were right in front of him. Critics use Orwell’s merciless reportorial skill as a brief against his imagination. His grim fantasy is all too realistic. It fails both as fantasy and prophesy. The titular date has come and gone, they point out. The world is not divided into three super powers perpetually at war; no telescreens invade our privacy. No all-powerful totalitarian state controls our lives, which are in fact more free and prosperous than anyone could have imagined at the bleak and dreary end of the Second World War. Of the computer and the internet, plausibly the most significant new developments since that time, Orwell had not an inkling. But this superficial reading of the book, whereby we comfort ourselves with the fact that we drink Bombay Sapphire rather than Victory Gin, is tragically naive and misguided. In fact every basic concept, every philosophical and political development Orwell addressed in his book has come to pass almost exactly as described.Orwell analyzed the way people driven by the need for power actually think. This is the most useful insight in his book, delivered by the Grand Inquisitor O’Brien:“The Party seeks power entirely for it’s own sake. We are not interested in the good of others; we are interested solely in power. Not wealth or luxury, or long life or happiness: only power, pure power … We know that no one ever seizes power with the intention of relinquishing it. Power is not a means it is an end. One does not establish a dictatorship to safeguard a revolution; one makes a revolution to establish the dictatorship. The object of persecution is persecution. The object of torture is torture … How does one man assert his power over another? … By making him suffer. Obedience is not enough. Unless he is suffering how can you be sure he is obeying your will and not his own? Power is in inflicting pain and humiliation. Power is in tearing human minds to pieces and putting them together again in new shapes of your own choosing. If you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face – forever.”To this bleak vision the battered and terrified Winston Smith has one reply: “Somehow you will fail. Something will defeat you. Life will defeat you.”Of course in the novel it is Winston Smith who is defeated and obliterated, after learning to love Big Brother. The story is unrelenting, a harsh tragedy in which the human spirit is crushed, and the future is too horrible to contemplate. The good guys lose. They are forced to betray their deepest beliefs and emotions, gutted of their souls and left to wander the streets like hollow eyed ghosts. Evil wins, over and over again, with a shriek of glee and blare of military music. The book ought to be profoundly depressing And yet it isn’t.  Just the opposite: it’s uplifting, thrilling. It’s a form of meta-text: the fact that you are reading the book at all, the fact that the book was written and published, confounds the darkness of its message. Winston Smith knows no one will ever read his journal … but people will be reading the novel that contains it for as long as books exist. The authors of the Newspeak dictionary exult in the destruction of language; the mandarins of the inner Party continuously dismantle all passion and morality and truth.  But the novel itself, with its vivid prose and ferocious probity creates an exhilaration, a giddy hope  in the reader that its characters can never share. A masterpiece. Read it. If you've already read it, read it again."

"Welcome to Oceania.  Our guide to this world is Winston Smith, a member of The Party who works at the Ministry of Truth making sure that all documents conform to The Party line.  And in this socialist vision of the world, The Party, as embodied by Big Brother, is all powerful.However, Winston is old enough to have vague memories of life before The Party took over England.  While he outwardly tows the line, he is hoping that at some point The Party can be overthrown.  As he starts a forbidden affair with Julia, it looks like his hopes might come to be.  Do they have hope of overthrowing the government?  Or is Big Brother really all powerful?I know I read this book back in high school, but that was a few years ago, so I decided it was time to read it again.  As a novel, it isn’t that good.  There are long, preachy passages and it’s easy to let your mind start to wander.  Yes, some world building is needed, but entirely too much of it takes place.However, in a study of how a totalitarian government can take over power and never let it go, this book is chilling.  And before you shake it off and say, “That would never happen here,” look around.  I see it happening on both sides of the spectrum, and politicians on both sides encouraging it.  We need to start heeding the warning that Orwell put in this book before we become part of Oceania.So read this book.  Think about it.  And figure out how you will keep the government from turning into Big Brother."

"In London, England a man named Winston was in his apartment writing in his dairy his memories that he has. Winston isn’t really supposed to be writing in the diary because the government doesn’t want the people to be able to think. If people think then the government thinks the people won’t listen and obey them so they took away all things that would make people think for themselves. This dystopian story, 1984, by George Orwell, is about Winston’s journey with a controlling government that is constantly watching their citizens.Winston meets a beautiful brunette named Julia, who is young and free spirited. Julia is the type of girl who doesn’t care what people think about her, she just wants to live her life and be happy.  After Julia sends him a secret note, they start a heated affair and they both become attached to each other. Julia really opens Winston’s eyes for him to see that there is more to life than being a product of the government, and when Winston sees that he falls in love with her.Big Brother is the name of the government, who controls every aspect of a person. The government’s job is to make these people how the government wants them.  Big brother controls their history, and all types of information the people know. The Party also forces individuals to suppress their sexual desires, treating sex as merely a procreative duty whose end is the creation of new Party members. Big Brother also uses kids and cops to make sure no one breaks the rules. This government represents communist/dictatorship type of government.O’Brian is part of big brother secretly. O’Brian is a very sketch and untrustworthy person throughout the book. He is one of those people who you think they are your friend but when you turn around they backstab you. O’Brian betrays Winston and Julia after he becomes their friend and leads them into the wrong path only to get them caught.The biggest theme in this book is danger of totalitarianism, totalitarianism can really destroy people. Big Brother conditions the minds of their victims with physical torture; the Party is able to control reality, convincing its subjects that 2 + 2 = 5. When the government has so much control over people it’s like they aren’t even living, they are just the product of the government walking around not realizing all the wrong that is around them.Another theme is physical manipulation, where the government undermines family structure by inducting children into an organization called the Junior Spies, which brainwashes and encourages them to spy on their parents and report any instance of disloyalty to the Party. The Party then channels people’s pent-up frustration and emotion into intense, ferocious displays of hatred against the Party’s political enemies. Many of these enemies have been invented by the Party expressly for this purpose.1984 was a very disturbing but interesting book. It was complicated to read but had a decent story line. I feel like readers can relate to Winston and his struggles that he goes through in the book but only to an extent. The author does an amazing job explain how big brother works"
"George Orwell’s Oceania in England made me feel as if I were in a prison.  The walls were closed in airplanes and telescreen’s are all around watching your every move. Winston Smith, the protagonist of 1984 plays an outsider working for the Ministry of Truth while enduring the pain of his revolting spirit. George Orwell is stunning in his dystopian novel about futuristic thoughts of the Communist movement by using a fictional character Big Brother.Winston is the reason that this book has been so outstandingly preserved through the years. He makes you feel as if you were there with him living his sham of a life. Winston works at the Ministry of truth where he distorts history. He takes real history and changes it so they can never be wrong. He falls in love with a rebel named Julia who doesn’t abide by all the rules set before society. She passes Winston a love note confessing her love for him.1984 is filled with unique characters such as Julia, O’Brien, and Syme. Orwell makes these characters seem futuristic by showing the down trodden nature of emotional appeal that the society has. The Government has ripped all the knowledge from them, they cannot tell real from fake.Julia, Obrien, and Syme are all a work of art, but the scariest enigma that the book warns us about is Big Brother. Winston writes the story through his eyes as an outsider; he wants the people of the future to know about his cruel lifeless world. He tries hard to rebel and break free from conformity, even though many obstacles hold him back.The main theme of the story is about psychological manipulation and how the Government can persuade you to think a certain way. Winston sees this every day; as the book goes on.An example:Every morning the citizens of Ingsoc have to wake up and complete a series of physically demanding exercise called physical jerks. The children fall as victims believing in lies and terrorizing adult citizens who rebel against the great Big Brother.Even though the story takes place in 1984 and was written in 1949, this classic dystopian novel paved a way for other novels wanting to expose the corruption of high profiled Government and societal conformity such as  Divergent by Veronica Roth.You’d think in a peaceful world a man and woman should be able to live their lives in happiness. "‘1984’ is George Orwell’s final, but probably one of his most significant novels. The author, Eric Arthur Blair, lived in the first half of the 20th century and was highly influenced by the social and political events of the era. His experience originated in the world wars, the events in Spain in the 1930s, the Cold War and the possibility of atomic warfare. Therefore, the novel describes a terrible dystopian imaginary future ruled by totalitarian government. It is a world of surveillance, public manipulation and limited liberty of speech. The novel is told in third person and shows the events in viewpoint of Winston Smith. Actually, I think that Smith is the character in the novel who represents Orwell’s opinion about the world and mainly about totalitarianism. It is evident for me that he refuses this kind of ruling and maybe he would try to warn people that terrible state can happened in the world easily if the trend continues in this way.The setting is London, the capital of “Airstrip One”, located in Oceania. Similarly to the Cold War, after a global war, the world is shared between three intercontinental superpowers – one of them is Oceania – which are in constant war with one another. Each state is governed by a totalitarian regime annihilating democratic features as well as personal individuality, human emotion, love, privacy and freedom. I consider the use of language as one of the most powerful features of the novel. In my opinion Orwell recognised the power of language and it appears in the novel as a powerful device of limitation of people’s thinking. Many new terms and phrases are in the novel, such as Newspeak, the official language of Oceania. Grammatically, Newspeak is similar to the English, but it has much lower vocabulary which is shrinking day by day in order to limit citizens’ thinking and avoid them from committing thoughtcrime. An engineer mentions in the novel that “in the end we shall make thoughtcrime literally impossible, because there will be no words in which to express it”. Through language, Orwell shows exceedingly how authority can influence and mislead people. Orwell uses themes from life in the Soviet Union and wartime life in Great Britain from which several ideas and terms have become famous. The slogan “Big Brother is watching you” maybe called into being today reality shows where participants are observed through cameras as citizens are watched through the telescreen in the novel. The term „2+2=5” has also origin in the Soviet Union. Two years after the Soviet Union had started its first five-year economic plan in 1928, the statistics presented that the plan was so successful that they would manage to finish it within four years. Therefore, the 2+2=5 slogan was started to propagate on posters. In the novel this term also appears when the protagonist Winston Smith think about it in connection with the power of the party. He meditates whether the authority can give people to believe it and if everybody believe it, whether it will be true."

"I read this book for pleasure over 40 years ago and rereading now brings a deeper appreciation of what Orwell was trying to say. The point I got all those years ago was about socialism and the suppression of individuality for the sake of happiness. This time I walked away with quite a different impression, name,t that conformity in all aspects of human existence IS necessary for a society to function, as a well oiled machine. The constant war, keeps the sheep in their place and is eerily like the sputum the neo-conservative world view keeps trying to foist upon American society. The illusion of freedom of thought is buttressed through the real masters namely the faceless boards that control the multinational corporations that are slowly creating their own newspeak and suppressing the individual in all walks of life. There is more to this book though, than prescient telling of Power for the sake Power.The lesson in this dated fable was not what the world had become, it was the systemic stripping of the ability and desire to think, question and arrive at conclusions through the examination of past. The past has always been rewritten by the winners and Orwell took that axiom and stretched it to its most logical conclusion.More to the point, I found the plot line and characters engaging and at no time did I stray out of the structure Orwell so artfully constructed. His world is complete and the motivations of each and every character is consistent throughout the tale. His language is terse and resembles newspeak its  staccato cadence and rhythm. Very few words are wasted on setting the scene and the darkness and dreariness of the life Winston Smith lives is echoed in the grey world in which he lives.Anyhow, an engrossing read that I will be thinking about for many days to come."
"The narrative of 1984 moves through four overlapping stages. In the first, the discontented Winston Smith, a lonely 39 year-old man and member of the Outer Party that rules Oceania, is tormented by his government’s continual and arbitrary adjustments to history and truth. Then, this Winston is noticed by Julia, another malcontent and cunning sexual adventurer, and they have an affair. In doing so, Winston gradually evolves from a mere “thought criminal” to a person who attempts to join the Brotherhood, which, in the rhetoric of the government, is an underground movement determined to overthrow the state.In stage two, Winston reads a political tract, supposedly written by the leader of the Brotherhood, which systematizes everything that Orwell has already shown his readers about Oceania. This tract, which Winston reads in bed while the indifferent Julia sleeps, explains why there is a shortage of consumer goods, endless warfare, an overwhelming Inner Party, and an effort to erode language.  This section of 1984 is brilliantly reasoned, albeit a trifle scholarly, and Orwell keeps it short.In the third stage, Winston and Julia are arrested and Orwell examines, step by step, the torture that Winston endures as the government, determined to “correct a flaw in the pattern,” converts him to a model citizen. Many Americans who read this section of 1984 might feel shame about their own government’s recent and similar activities. Finally, Orwell puts the reader inside the head of the reformed Winston in this novel’s fourth stage, when he thinks like his fellow citizens. This stage, a short and chilling final chapter, shows what Winston has become after losing his individuality.IMHO, 1984 deserves its reputation as a great book and it still works. This is so because Orwell has imagined a credible dystopian society, in which the dominant Inner Party is obsessed with its goals of retaining control and perpetuating itself. The novel also works because Orwell has created two amazing characters—Winston Smith and O’Brien—who, at the start of this book, hold opposite ideas about the truth.One quibble: Orwell creates a situation in which one final betrayal breaks Winston’s character. But does torture really work this way—that is, depend on a single psychological event to flip a person’s affiliations and beliefs forever? This seemed to me more literary than true.Regardless, my recommendation is: Read it again! You’ll enjoy 1984 more than you did in high school."

"Orwell's most famous work, ""Nineteen Eighty Four"", written in 1949 is still as gripping, poignant and terrifying as it must have been over 60 years ago. My review is for the unabridged audio CD, skillfully read by Simon Prebble. Orwell describes a dystopian society in the country of Oceania, in which war is permanent, government surveillance is widespread, individualism and all forms of self expression are suppressed, and ""big brother"" is watching. Though this novel has been on every ""Top 100"" reading list as well as high school and college curriculums for decades, somehow I had put off reading it until now. I was quite surprised at how relevant it still is, ensuring that it will remain on required reading lists for many decades to come.The main character, Winston Smith, works at the Ministry of Truth, as part of a team that is constantly rewriting history to suit the purposes of the current party line. No one is sure who ""big brother"" really is, or even if such a person exists. Citizens are constantly programmed with ""double think"" phrases such as ""Ignorance is strength"", ""war is peace"", and ""freedom is slavery"". They fear the thought police who will punish them severely for not adhering to party teachings, even in their thoughts. Society is plagued by constant shortages, scarcity and hardships, primarily due to constant wars. The Machine believes in constant warfare to get rid of materials that might make the masses comfortable and complacent. The Party's main purpose is to mold the consciousness of the masses, and was described at one point as a ""boot stamping on a human face.""The themes of nationalism, censorship and surveillance are just as relevant today as they were over 60 years ago, ensuring that this novel will remain in the forefront of literature for a long time to come. It's not an easy book to read, since the deprivation, brainwashing and torture are hard to endure. However, I suspect that I will read it again and again because of the many levels of meaning and message."
Reread this book after 50 years since it was required reading at school. Amazing! Highly recommend reading by every high school student. Uncannily reminiscent of current events.
are you kidding...just look around!!!!!

"I’ve been wanting to read this book for years. I was fascinated by the idea of it when I first learned about it in high school. The futuristic world was intriguing, and to know that the often-used phrase of ""Big Brother"" comes from this book, made it even more appealing.I remember hearing in high school that Orwell was writing this novel in 1948 (even though it was later published in 1949). Therefore, when choosing the year for his dystopian future, he flipped the final two numbers to create 1984. There are so many interesting science fiction ideas developed by Orwell (the Thought Police and Telescreens, just to name a couple).One warning for readers, though. This book isn’t immediately accessible. You need to stick with it, and plow through some of the parts that seem to be dragging on. The book is split into three parts, and while I felt engaged during Parts 2 and 3, Part 1 took me a long time to get through.FINAL RATING: 3.5 stars out of a possible 5SLIGHT SPOILERS:This is not a happy book. This is not a fun adventure. As opposed to modern dystopian fiction, there isn't a hero that leads a rebellion against a corrupt ruler. Instead, this book is about total loss of self in response to a tyrannical government. Instead of a grand, far-reaching story, this book explores how living in a dystopian world slowly tears a man down, and strips him of his very identity. The end of this man's story was truly depressing."

"I don't know if this is considered a ""classic"" or not, but it's definitely one of those ""books teachers make you read in school."" Because of that, I went into this somewhat reluctantly. It's a book I've always wanted to read, mostly because I just felt obligated to read, but I didn't think I'd really enjoy it.I was pleasantly surprised by how enjoyable it actually was. Maybe ""enjoyable"" is the wrong word. I mean, let's be honest: this is a pretty depressing, almost horrifying book. If you want something uplifting, don't read 1984, because you're probably going to walk away from it feeling pretty awful. But it was much easier to read and get absorbed in than I had expected. The characters are a bit bland, but I thought that actually fit very well considering the setting. The plot had little twists and turns that kept things interesting, but I think what really drew me in was just how thought-provoking this book is. The world George Orwell has created definitely resonates with some of the things we see in our world today, and even though the year 1984 has come and gone, I think this is a book that will remain relevant for decades to come."

"In the fictional nation of Oceania, Winston Smith, a low ranking member of the controlling party, works in the Ministry of Truth. His job is to alter past events to fall in line with the party’s propaganda.  Though Winston holds a low level position, it is an important one. In Oceania, The strongest tool for keeping order in the nation is thought control. To achieve this, the leaders of the controlling party have installed telescreens, in every room to watch over all people and prevent anything called thoughtcrime. This invasion of privacy forces Winston into constant paranoia. Winston’s disapproval of the ruling party leads him to join a secret anti-Party group, the Brotherhood, with his secret lover Julia.  The man whom Winston believed to be a powerful member of the Brotherhood, O’Brien, turns out to be a member of the Party. With Winston and Julia’s thoughtcrime noted, the Party then takes Winston to the Ministry of Love then to the dreaded Room 101. To avoid giving away too many spoilers, my summary will end with Winston in the control of the Party. I recommend this book to everybody, as it is one of my favorite books. It gives an in depth look into a totalitarian government all while making it a fun read. If you have any interest in the Soviet Union or communism, this book is for you."

"This is my favorite book of all time.  Absolutely incredible.Anyone who gave this book a bad rating (3 or under) is, quite simply, incorrect.  No, they don't just have a different yet equally valid opinion.  They simply got this one wrong.  The idea that a book or a movie could be objectively good, despite garnering some small amount of negative reviews, really shouldn't be a controversial idea.  Go to rotten tomatoes and look up any movie that is objectively great, and I guarantee it won't be at 100%.  That means certain critics (usually a very small minority) leave scathing reviews of even some of the greatest movies ever made.  The same thing happens with books, and it is what has happened here anytime you see a review that's 3 or less.  I'm not saying it has to be everyone's favorite book like it is mine.  But I am saying that it's an amazing book, objectively.  A 4 out of 5 is about the lowest I could imagine a reasonable person going."

"I have now read the most terrifying, frightening, horrifying book of all time, a chilling prophecy of a future that is both impossible not to read once you start, and hard to keep going in a lot of place. I LOVED 1984 by George Orwell. I now know that there is nothing that Stephen King or anyone else can tell that can ever arouse in me the fear, the shudder, the horrors of The Thought Police and Big Brother and the unforgettably disturbing O'Brien character.I never read this book in high school, so when it showed up on Kindle Unlimited, I snatched it - lucky for me, the audio came along with it. Double the horror, the terror, the fright. First, I begin by saying that I find it mildly ironic that in 1984, I lived in a place that was a figment of Orwell's predictions, in the Islamic Revolution of Iran, and while reading this difficult-to-digest masterpiece, the memories that I was certain I had long forgotten only came back into clear view. Winston was not a character you fell in love with or madly cared about, but he was an unfortunate victim of a mad world running on mad logic, mad government and mad laws. It was madness, I kept thinking as did Winston Smith, how can they do this? And yet they did. The bleak dark dismal world that George Orwell painted will remain intact in my mind for eternity, because it touched on the thing I fear the most - and that is something you do not forget easily.The writing is exquisite, superb, thunderous to the beating heart of the reader which has already slowed down a good amount. The story telling is so powerful that sometimes you just draw yourself out of the plot and just listen with joy - did I mention I was listening to it mostly? - listen to the art of writing, the perfection in the craft. If only the story were less dismal, less bleak, more tolerable, and I admit I almost put it down, I almost couldn't take it when they were discovered and then I thought, I owe it to George Orwell, I owe it to him to finish what he set out to tell us, and I will not stop until the very last words.Someone commented that she hated Julia. I found this intriguing. I do put down books when I hate the main character or even a major secondary character but 1984 was different. I did not read this book to love or hate any character, - there were no heroes here, and although I hated quite a few, I don't think love for the characters was the emotion that came to mind. Connecting with them and feeling their pain more than anything was my reason for staying with them to the end.I have to admit there is one section I did not like - and could not appreciate - and that was Goldstein's manuscript. It was necessary to the story, it was important to Orwell to write that I am sure, but it took away from the story and the plot both, and it was deeply complex - I was glad when Winston put the book down and the story continued .... but as I write this, I realize that not being able to appreciate this part of the book makes me more like Julia's character, and I wish Julia cared more about the manuscript too. But then again, what difference would it have made? None whatsoever.A recent book I finished, which had another most chilling effect on me from a dystopian future was Margaret Atwood's A Handmaid's Tale, and I can see so many parallels between the two and after looking it up, I'm not at all surprised that Atwood was indeed influenced by 1984 to write the story of the Republic of Gilead, a state ruled by religious fundamentalists. So if you enjoyed Orwell's 1984 - yes I do realize ""enjoy"" may not be the appropriate word, ooooh I wonder what the Newspeak term for it would be !!! - anyway if you appreciated Orwell's work, you will appreciate A Handmaid's Tale.Next for me, Animal Farm. I don't expect an upbeat story in that one either. Oh well, it shall be so as it must be done. Hope this review helps you decide whether to read or move on from the book. And on top of that, appreciate the fact that you indeed do have the freedom to CHOOSE, a priceless gift that you would miss sorely if it were stripped from you by the Thought Police. Just sayin'."

"Winston Smith lives in England under a totalitarian government called ""the Party"". Winston works in The Ministry of Truth as a person who alters the history of the world. But one day, Winston meets up with a lady named Julia and they commit their lives to the Brotherhood, an anti-government group. It goes well for Winston and Julia, until they become outlaws wanted by the Party.1984 is an excellent book. The author of Animal Farm and this novel,George Orwell created a thrilling and intense story. He creates a feeling to the reader that something is wrong with this ""government"". The government in Winston's society doesn't want people to know about the past.If they do, they may rebel. So, in response, they alter the present so Winston's government can look to them as superior. In effect, citizens of ""Oceania"", where Winston lives, are completely oblivious to what really has happened in the past. Moreover, the government wants people to know what they're doing so that they don't rebel. For example, there are laws against ""thoughtcrime"". ""Thoughtcrime"" is a crime committed in your thoughts like having hatred for the Party, but in secret. Another example of this is the government sets up cameras and microphones everywhere so they can bust people for ""thoughtcrime"". One of the goals of Winston's government is to take over the world and enforce their law around the world. The man at the top of all of this is Big Brother. He's the supreme ruler of Oceania. He's the one in charge of everything; the Party, the agencies and his people. While living in this world, Winston learns of the Brotherhood, an anti-Party agency. he decides to join this agency because he feels that something is wrong about his government and he wants to change it and give everybody their freedoms back.When 1984 was first published in 1949, it generally got excellent reviews. Some of these reviews came from V.S. Pritchett, P.H. Newby, and Bertrand Russell. But a negative review of the book came from Edward Shanks, a book reviewer for the Sunday Times. Shanks claimed that 1984 ""Breaks all records for gloomy vaccination"". I do not agree with Shanks's review of 1984. I think it's a great book with a lot of adventure, suspense, and action. So all in all, it's a great book and I encourage everybody to read it."
"This book will never be outdated. It is obvious to see why it's still a required reading in most schools. Although, true appreciation for this book comes with maturity. Everyone should read it at least once."

"This marks the third time I've read this book (previously in 1989 at the age of 14, and again in 2007).One of the most important novels ever written, but also one of the most depressing (though the tone and manner in which the Appendix is written does offer the reader a wee-bitty glimmer of hope). More frighteningly relevant than ever: on the one hand, sure, thankfully, 31 years after ""1984"" was supposed to have taken place (and 67 years after it was actually written), democracy and capitalism still exist, and the Iron Curtain has collapsed; on the other hand, seeing how even in the free-market democracies, Big Government has gotten more and more intrusive into private citizens' lives (see the NSA surveillance scandal in the US, the presence of CCTV cameras on practically every street corner in London, the ability of spy satellites in geosynchronous orbit thousands of miles above the Earth to take close up shots of people and property alike), not to mention any idiot with a camera phone to record your activities and emulate the Junior Spies of Orwell's book, and it becomes readily apparent that the technological potential for a Big Brother-type omnipresent superstate is stronger than ever. The year 1984 may have come and gone, but lovers of civil liberty need to be more vigilant than ever in this day and age, and reading Orwell's book helps to drive that point home."

"The dystopian literature classic ""1984"" by George Orwell is known today by the general public through catchphrases and Super Bowl commercials, however the introduction of the ""Orwellian nightmare"" this novel presented in the late 1940s were eye-opening at the time.The novel begins with Winston Smith making his way to his apartment and putting his crimethink into practice by starting a diary.  We then follow Winston as continues his one-man rebellion against Big Brother and the Party.  Soon Winston finds a comrade in Julia, a rebel from the waist down, and the two begin an affair.  The affair and their rebellion ends when the Thought Police arrest them, led by Inner Party leader O'Brien, who Winston believed to be a rebel as well.  Then Winston is tortured and brainwashed into becoming a loving member of the Party, happy to return Big Brother's love and can not wait to announce his crimes.The broken and oppressive world in which Winston lives is a stunning contrast to what the reader is accustomed to as well as the contradictory political language that the Party uses in its rule.  These foundational constructions by Orwell using Winston's internal thoughts help the reader understand the Oceania of 1984 as well as Winston's acceptance of already being dead.  The misunderstanding by Winston of who was his friend and who was his enemy is done expertly by Orwell, giving the novel breathe as well as some added character depth.  Orwell's unsettling writing of Winston's imprisonment, torture, and brainwashing make the last third of the book the most powerful as we see the character we've gotten to know for almost 200 pages change in front of our eyes.However, Orwell's Party doesn't seem that bright given what O'Brien states during Winston's torture.  The Thought Police had been following Winston for seven years, which meant they were allowing Winston to potentially infect other Party members with his crimethink.  The fact that they were able to capture Julia, a rebel of her own, seems like an attempt by Orwell to save the Party's face but it only makes it more glaring.  For all their talk of power, they seemed pretty powerless to just let Winston keep walking around free for seven years.  This one flaw leads to the reader noticing some others less egregious flaws in the overall work, but nothing that doesn't effect the overall quality of the writing.In the end, the themes and ideas that Orwell introduced continue to be debated even today with government surveillance and media manipulation.  However what Orwell could never have imagined was the individual people could compete with the government and media in distorting the truth by way of Photoshop.  ""1984"" is a warning about how man could be robbed of his human nature either through passive education or more extreme persuasion, the story of Winston Smith keeps reminding the reader that everyone needs to fight to keep their basic nature."

"George Orwell’s 1984 explores an entirely new aspect of human nature, and causes readers to think about the future of society. 1984 begins by introducing readers to the ever present and scary dictatorship of Big Brother, a fictitious and structured version of God. Big Brother is a surrounding and all controlling aspect of the book, creating a main-character vibe while focusing on the lives of many characters. Orwell writes 1984 in the late 1940s based on the influence of Nazi Germany, illustrating a dark society and providing readers with his image of England under totalitarian rule. Big Brother exists to control every aspect of life and every second of time. Orwell exemplifies a Government that has rewritten all history books, forces its citizens to keep their television screens on at all times, promotes “hate” propaganda that evaporates any thoughts concerning rebellion, and monitors their relationships.  The novel takes place in a depressing and dark time. There is never enough food, clothes or resources to accommodate everyone, overall adding to the cynical and depressing mood of the story. In addition to the creepy surveillance of the government, the characters never seem to understand what is going on. For example, there is a war and bombs that kill people in the streets that no one understands or even seems to question.  Readers are introduced to Big Brother from the viewpoints of the main character, Winston Smith, who secretly wants to rebel against Big Brother. Winston tests the boundaries by keeping a secret journal to preserve the past and to reflect on his thoughts. Towards the middle of the book, Winston starts to form relationships, which are considered illegal. A romantic bond is formed between our main character and a girl named Julia, who shares Winston’s hate for the controlling and overpowering “party.” A friendship is also formed between Winston and a man named O’Brien, whom Winston is drawn to, and believes they share an intellectual connection.  O’Brien is introduced to the relationship between Julia and Winston, and in the end, betrays his good “friend.” O’Brein turns out to be a powerful and sophisticated member the Inner Party. The thought police capture Julia and Winston and root out all ideas of rebellion. They are carried off to Ministry of Love for torture, and ultimately both Winston and Julia betray their feelings towards one another. The government brain washes and breaks Winston and Julia, and readers discover the dominant cruelty of Big Brother. In conclusion, Big Brother wanted to exercise complete power, and in the end, “He loved Big Brother.”  Thus, the main idea of George Orwell’s 1984, was to emphasize an idea of the future, and to demonstrate to readers that a human being can be broken down completely, even if it is 2+2=5, like the teachings of Big Brother. However, Orwell leaves readers with a positive message too, showcasing the trouble and hardship to push people to a place where they can be broken and dominated by someone else’s thoughts."

"1984 is probably the best-written book I've pulled from the shelf to date. That there's an absorbing and urgent narrative here as well is icing on the Orwellian cake. The lessons of Oceania transcend era and have lasting value for those working to organize and uplift society.It's as if Orwell has reached into the future and touched the mood of the present. One can connect with ease Orwell's cautionary dystopia to the depredations of American privacy that have surfaced in just the last couple of years. Much of 1984's quirky ""Newspeak""--terms like thoughtcrime, doublethink and Big Brother--have been absorbed into the modern idiom. Among the rarefied collective of the greatest writers the English language has ever known, George Orwell painstakingly crafted a penetrating, prophetic tale, a world within a world, a spiraling ideascape whose tendrils integrate seamlessly with the realities of modern life.Here's a small sampling of the winged brilliance flanking the reader at every turn:""He was a fattish but active man of paralyzing stupidity, a mass of imbecile enthusiasms - one of those completely unquestioning, devoted drudges on whom, more even than on the Thought Police, the stability of the Party depended."" (p. 22)""She had a bold, aquiline face, a face that one might have called noble until one discovered that there was as nearly as possible nothing behind it."" (p. 66)""Until they become conscious they will never rebel, and until after they have rebelled they cannot become conscious."" (p. 70)""But there was still that memory moving round the edges of his consciousness, something strongly felt but not reducible to definite shape, like an object seen out of the corner of one's eye."" (p. 122)""To hang on from day to day and from week to week, spinning out a present that had no future, seemed an unconquerable instinct, just as one's lungs will always draw the next breath so long as there is air available."" (p. 152)""What opinions the masses hold, or do not hold, is looked on as a matter of indifference. They can be granted intellectual liberty because they have no intellect."" (p. 210)Recommended companion reading:- Brave New World by Aldous Huxley (1932)- Amusing Ourselves to Death: Public Discourse in the Age of Show Business by Neil Postman (1985)"

"I sincerely believe that the famous writer George Orwell was a visionary. He has created a novel about a totalitarian regime. Unfortunately, even in our time, have countries that have established a totalitarian regime. In such countries, on the thrones still sits Big Brother. The main character with the usual surname Smith wanted to hack the system. He wanted to feel like a person, but not a wheel in a relentless state machine. But what could he do alone? Even when Smith met a girl with a companion on thoughts, they together entered into the abyss of oblivion. Their love was crushed like a flower, and soul destroyed. Under terrible torture that was carried out on them in the Ministry of Love, they were forced to betray each other. The world is endlessly at war somewhere, Big Brother IS watching you through your cellphone data, and history, as taught in our schools, is being rewritten to leave out things that we find unpleasant. We probably aren't quite at the ""1984"" stage yet, but we always have the threat hanging over us."

"1984 is not a happy novel. It’s depressing and at times, very hard to read. Rather than a novel, it is more George’s political statement, warning of the dangers of Totalitarianism, and oh yes, he wrapped this all around an insipid story of the life and death of one poor individual, Winston Smith. The main characters are banal and tedious in my opinion. In fact, I found O’Brien to be more interesting than Winston himself. The real star of the show, however, is Big Brother, the mythical God of 1984. All seeing, and all knowing, Big Brother, unlike the god of Catholic dogma, is powered by a network of spies and monitors, but he gets the job done...ruthlessly, and tangibly!I found parts of this story difficult to read, requiring concentration and re-reading parts. This was mainly in the recounting of THE BOOK, by Emmanuel Goldstein. Winston reads it to his girlfriend, and like her, I fell asleep too!There is no doubting the remarkable vision and foresight of the author, and his brilliant writing style, but it is not without fault. Many of Orwell's concepts are repeated ad nauseum (maybe on purpose?). One could be forgiven for thinking George might have been a time traveller. (I wonder what he would think about the fall of the USSR?) However, I just didn’t enjoy this book. It’s just too depressing, and I wouldn’t read any more of Orwell’s books, but I’m glad he wrote it. It still stands a salient warning about a social system that just doesn’t work.I give it just two stars, and in the words of Orwell himself, “Being in a minority, even a minority of one, did not make you mad”."

"Orwell's 1984 is a brilliant (although very bleak) novel which depicts a totalitarian future. All activities and thoughts are being watched by the government (""Big Brother"") and the truth is constantly being manipulated to the point where the society no longer has a history. The plot revolves around Winston Smith, a man who works for the Ministry of Truth by doctoring various documents and photographs in order to fit the current narrative that the government is telling citizens. Smith begins to challenge the Big Brother by committing small acts of rebellion. It starts with keeping a journal, then leads to a love affair, which leads him to want to look for ways of getting involved in a revolution.  First, let me say that Orwell's work is a product of its times in certain aspects - Britain had just been through two world wars which were only eighteen years apart. Orwell had also seen the rise of totalitarianism in Russia, Spain, Italy, and Germany. Yet Orwell, takes these aspects a step further into the future with the use of totalitarian sates, atomic weaponry, and the military industrial complex to create a very bleak new world. The writing and descriptions are wonderful. The book really makes you think, not only about society, but about history, happiness, love and the truth.  Second, I read the 1984 Commemorative Edition, this was rather interesting as it contains a rather insightful essay by Erich Fromm at the end and an interesting foreword by Walter Cronkite at the beginning. Cronkite discusses the book in relation to his experience with news and the news of the day ( which is rather interesting considering the edition is about thirty years old).  If you enjoy this I would strongly recommend Animal Farm by George Orwell, Brave New World by Aldous Huxley, and Amusing Ourselves To Death by Neil Postman. I would also recommend the show Futurama by the creators of the Simpsons, once you read 1984 you will see that the creators have taken many ideas from Orwell and Huxley."

Highly Recommended!"
