"Re-reading ""1984"" after 40 years, I was taken with how strong its writing and message remain. Although a product of its time - the totalitarian era of Hitler and Stalin - the book introduced many concepts that have relevance today: thoughtcrime and thought police, constant surveillance (through telescreens), Big Brother, perpetual wars, propaganda, and the use of torture to enforce conformity.The structure of ""1984"" is so good. (some spoilers ahead) Part 1 introduces us to Winston Smith, who works in the Ministry of Truth rewriting history in accordance with Party doctrine, chucking historical documentation down ""memory holes."" Part 1 reveals how the oppressive society of Oceania functions and shows Winston's growing disillusionment with it.Part 2 follows Winston as he begins to defy the system by becoming lovers with a woman named Julia and meeting up with and committing himself to the revolutionary actions of the underground Brotherhood. Part 3 covers Winston's captivity, interrogation, torture and reintegration into Oceania, ending with the chilling line: ""He loved Big Brother.""The language Orwell uses is lean and precise. The trajectory of ""1984"" is increasingly intense and nerve-wracking. These stylistic choices give his warning message great clarity and power. What a passion he must have been in as he wrote this novel! (In fact, Orwell was dying during the months he struggled to finish it.) Forty years after my first reading of ""1984,"" it's a book that still takes my breath away and scares the hell out of me. It's a book that deserves to be read, studied and admired."
"One of the most frightening stories ever told. I've read it at least four or five times, and it never ceases to haunt."
"I haven't read this book since my high school days, and even then, I never read the entire book. It is a cultural classic, but a pretty horrifying check on reality - for Orwell does not mince his words - this is raw, far more horrifying than any Hollywood ""horror"" film because his book depicts plausible reality. He presses home, paragraph after paragraph, page after page, with the subtlety of a sledgehammer, the future we would face were we to permit Big Brother to become a reality. I have not checked school curricullums lately, to see if this book is on the required reading list - but if not, that is a fatal error because 1984 is a manual, a text book for the anti-Christ of freedom - and required education for anyone living in a society which is edging towards ultra-surveillance, such as our own. I marvel at Orwell's ability, in 1949, to piece together such a picture and something of a vigilance. But I warn you, reading this book is not for the faint hearted - it's grimy, right down there at the gutter of humanity's low - slaves to a system."

"1984 presents some of the most interesting ideals that are caused when a society takes a turn down a path that no longer causes it to increase in technology and power but simply to increase in hate and arrogance. Setting in a dystopia future well past/ future of London we focus upon a main character who is moving through his life while simply trying to live. Soon he starts to break off and have thoughts about his life and his government that contradict what they want him to believe. Through a series of events Winston the main character has a love affair, a secret room, joins a brotherhood, and is captured all in the span of half a year. This book is great as the ideas of a totalitarian government are taken to the extreme when it is allowed to fester and control it citizens without a struggle this book demonstrates how far a government will go to try and control its people. The third part of this book is by far the most interesting as it finally shows the true nature of the government and the true determination of the party to try and keep there members from thinking anything other than what the government wants.  The effectiveness of this book comes from the fact that we never truly experience freedom in the book. The character does not achieve success, he does not necessarily find happiness and the government wins in the end. The book uses this to enforce the idea that this government and the way the people are isn’t going to change with a simple revolution. This oppression is so wide spread that it is impossible to have a simple revolution that in order for these societies to change a great wide spread ideal change must occur. Orwell writes this to give you the impression that nothing is going to change. He reinforces this by have the main character constantly in this state that nothing he does will change and that the possibility of him coming out of this in a positive way is slim to non. Orwell achieves a great amount of this by having the main character repeat the same things he believes and also by repeating the phrase we are dead. The most ideal heavy part of this novel is extremely effective in book two as Winston is reading the book. This book is used to shed more light on the conditions that Winston is living in and it truly expresses the fact that Winston lives in an age of war with fighting always going on and it never truly happening the book reinforces that all the ideals of the party are in a sense false and misguided. But using the book Orwell also instills hopelessness as he states that these super states are the same in the major sense and only differ slightly thus it is impossible for one to simply have a revolution as in each super-state is self contained."
"George Orwell was the great prophet of totalitarianism. His Homage to Catalonia (1938) sounded an early warning about the nature of the Soviet Communists in its depiction of how they attempted to subvert the Spanish Republican government even at the cost of helping the fascists in the short term. Animal Farm (1945) was a dissection of how the idealistic Russian revolution was co-opted by Stalinist totalitarians. Then came 1984, Orwell's culminating work, published just before his death of tuberculosis in early 1950.Unfortunately, I also think that his impending death impelled Orwell to run off the rails a bit in his dystopian vision. While the first part of the book is brilliant in its depiction of a society controlled and manipulated by an all-powerful state—read The Gulag Archipelago to see just how closely Orwell's fictional Oceania tracks the real-world Soviet state under Stalin—the second part following Winston Smith's arrest goes way overboard as Orwell seek to make a philosophical point about the subjection of the total man and also gross out readers as much as possible about just how horrible a world he can create. But to achieve this, Orwell has to sacrifice the integrity of his story.The whole premise of the first part was to give readers a disturbingly plausible vision of how a populace can be made to submit and acquiesce to its servitude to the state. The perpetual surveillance through the two-way video screens (creepily analogous to GPS trackers in today's electronic gadgets), the never-ending happy-talk propaganda, the bread-and-circuses mollification of the ""proles"" (what we today call ""low information voters"" in a delicious bit of real-life newspeak) and the realization that the best way to control a population is to keep them hopped up on a crusade in which ""we're all in it together"" (which is why governments today are eternally declaring ""war"" on everything from drugs to iliteracy)—all brilliant and brilliantly depicted.But then Winston Smith gets arrested and the verisimilitude vanishes. First of all, the whole idea that a police state would bother to make sexual indiscretion a capital crime is ridiculous (unless it has a theological basis such as in Medieval Christianity or modern Iran). Yes, I get it that it highlights Orwell's argument that a totalitarian state seeks to destroy everything human or individual in its subjects, but I think Aldous Huxley was on a much sounder ground in Brave New World where promiscuity was not only legal but encouraged. If you want to devastate the individual/spiritual integrity of a populace, it's better to turn them into beasts thant monks.But my biggest criticism is how the narrative runs aground during O'Brien's ongoing interrogation and torture of Smith. For this to be plausible, we have to believe that this high muckety-muck in the Oceania hierarchy would have spent the last seven years minutely tracking the activities of a mid-level worker drone, and then spent considerable state resources to capture and torture this individual over an extended period. And for what? So that he can destroy ""the last man"" as Smith is unconvincingly termed? The conclusion to be drawn seems to be that once the last independent thinker is snuffed out, there won't be any more of them. If only, says ever tyrant in history. Frankly, O'Brian comes off as an obsessive loon and if I were Big Brother, I would seriously consider getting him off the payroll for pursuing a private agenda with state resources. Who knows what he'll fixate on next.Yes, I understand that Orwell's point was to show as brutally as possible the stamping out of individualism, but he could have saved the tedious lectures O'Brien (and Emanuel Goldstein through the extended excerpts from his book) foists on poor Smith (and the reader) and simply continued to show life in Oceania. That to me was by far the most compelling part of this book."
"This is a great book, but if you're a kind of fiction-, fantasy-loving book reader, I don't think this book is for you. However, its insight on political structure is amazing! I think it is a critical read for the youth of our age."

"With countless book reviews already written about George Orwell's mid 20th-century literary classic, the task of writing one with unique value seems daunting. 1984 is a novel about a man, Winston, living in a dystopian society called Oceania where everyone is being monitored by a totalitarian government. Winston meets a young woman, Julia, and they must hide their forbidden relationship from the eyes and ears of Big Brother, the ruling figurehead whose image is displayed on posters in every room, hallway and building.Apart from the political commentary and sometimes endearing affair between Winston and Julia, I found 1984 to be quite disturbing and somewhat perverted, which I assume is what Orwell intended. The filth, poverty and pain described throughout adds to the distaste in your mouth whitle reading and accentuates the utter disdain one feels for the society made up of Big Brother, the Inner Party(ruling class), the Outer Party(middle-class), and the Proles(lower-class poor).To me, 1984 is first and foremost about power; unfettered, unyielding, and unforgiving power. The main theme examines absolute collectivism versus individualism, while the political commentary about capitalism versus socialism is secondary.There are several parallels that can be drawn between Orwell's dystopia and today's society not least of which being the constant surveillance of the telescreens and microphones placed everywhere to monitor the masses in Oceania. According to a passage in a forbidden book that Winston is secretly given, the main device that brought about the all powerful government into being was a television that could both transmit and receive. This device, called a telescreen, installed in virtually every room in every building, is what separated Big Brother from all other dictatorships, authoritarian, totalitarian and socialist governments because it enabled the complete control of the people; not just their actions, but their thoughts as well. We have TVs, computers, cameras and GPS devices everywhere in our society today that can serve this purpose.Orwell's attack on collectivism is equally frightening when he describes the blind and violent hatred that the populous exhibits towards traitors, rebels, and foreign enemies. It reminds me of some of the reality shows of our time where people gather together to celebrate the humiliation, rejection or failure of others. All written and recorded media is constantly revised to support the interests of the Party. History is continuously revised.In Oceania, there is no crime and no punishment for criminals according to Big Brother. Instead, people are monitored and eliminated if it appears from their behavior that they might commit a crime in the future, which sounds a lot like what the NSA has as it's goal in fighting terrorism.  Further, to control the fear of the populous of Oceania, and drive the economy, there is always a war going on with another part of the world, driven by the lust for more power and control of cheap labor.  This sounds familiar too.The big difference between Orwell's dystopia and our current Western society is that Big Brother's goal is to eliminate all forms of pleasure in order to prevent people from becoming satisfied thereby reducing their hatred by which the government is using to control them. Artificial insemination is the preferred method of procreation and the family unit is one in which the children spy on their parents. Many blogs, books and articles have been written about the degradation of the family unit in today's society.The one passage that strikes at the heart of a totalitarian, surveillance society that we should remember and consider a warning is ""That the choice for mankind lay between freedom and happiness and for the bulk of mankind happiness was better."" This could be the slogan of the NSA."
"1984 is an amazing book which is as relevant today as it was when it was written in the late 1940's.  The original dystopia/post-apocalyptic fiction.  This was my gateway drug into PA/Dystopia fiction and I keep comparing everything against 1984.  If you have note read it before, please do.  It is just one of those books everyone should read!~="
"1984 is very well written and sends a very clear and important message to the world. Orwell crafted one of the best dystopian books I have ever read. The atmosphere absolutely chilling and every detail is wonderfully placed throughout the novel. There were, however, some short sections of the book that made is a little bit boring.The characters throughout the book are very interesting. 1984 follows the life of Winston Smith, a middle class man living out his life in the city of London. We follow his life as his thoughts, personality, and outlook change with encounters with events and other people. Only a few characters really make a prominent impact throughout the entire novel. However, these characters really help bring out the character of the book.The book sends a very clear message about authoritarian power and the problems of an over controlling government. The events throughout the book show how life could be like if the governments become powerful. The ruling elites establish absolute control over the middle and lower classes of society. Near the middle of the book, Orwell sneaks in passages explaining some sort of political theory that explains the situation in the world in 1984. This part adds to increasing knowledge imparted to us through Orwell's novel.There are some points throughout the book were I found myself trying to keep reading. The middle section of the book is a clear example of this. This part of the book really dragged on even though it was only a small section of the book. It started out pretty interesting but it begun to drag as it got longer.1984 is a very good book. The message is sends about the dangers of the power of the government is truly amazing and furthered my view on the world. It is clear that this book set the stage for other books just like it. However, it is not for everyone. Some of the nightmarish scenarios presented could turn off some people. 1984  is an amazing book and everyone should try to read it at one point in their lifetime."

"Re-reading this book today, as so many people are doing, reminds us of how gloomy the world looked in 1949. And especially how gloomy it looked to Orwell, who had spent his entire life and lost his health in struggles for what he imagined as a more decent society — one where people cared about and cared for one another. The book is a biting satire of what he thought of as the muddle-headed reformism of the British Labour Party, heading toward a totally controlled society called ""Ingsoc"", Newspeak for ""English Socialism"", but the permanent anxiety-inducement, psychological manipulation through the distortion of language, and crude but effective torture were inspired more by Nazi Germany and, especially, Stalin's Soviet Union. The technology of surveillance by ""Big Brother"" seems laughably primitive today, in the face of Edward Snowden's revelations about the working of the NSA, but Orwell's vision of pseudo-friendships among individuals too frightened to really connect seems almost to foreshadow those on Facebook and Twitter.Orwell's great strength was as a moral essayist, a writer with a very definite view of how things ought to be and a critique of all that fell short of that. And it is as a moral essay that this book continues to matter, not as an effort of belles lettres. It is not pleasing to read, the flow of the language is jarring, the characters unlovable and barely understandable as people — and that is surely just what Orwell intended. But those unlikeable characters all serve his two purposes: to point out the dangers of an all-controlling state and to remind us once again of how language can be corrupted in ways not to advance and express thought, but to impede it. And also perhaps to express one faint hope: Winston Smith, by resisting as long as he does, even though he finally succumbs, demonstrates that the system's control can never be absolutely complete."

War is a way of shattering to pieces, or pouring into the stratosphere, or sinking in the depths of the sea, materials which might otherwise be used to make the masses too comfortable, and hence, in the long run, too intelligent. Even when weapons of war are not actually destroyed, their manufacture is still a convenient way of expending labor power without producing anything that can be consumed... On the other hand, he is the author of a provocation, demonstrating at the very least differentiation within, but also perhaps determinate contradiction within what is no longer a singularity. But this invites us to critically reflect on the social location of this dissident place ""outside"" the frame? What is the new frame that includes both these places? What has been left untheorized or undertheorized in 1984?"

"1st sentence: ""It was a cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen.""Thirteen? Clocks don't strike thirteen, at least not in the world I live in. This is a brilliant opening sentence. You immediately know something is off, the world has changed. And if you suffer from triskaidekaphobia then you already have little warning bells sounding in your head.The world Orwell created is divided into three super states that came to power after a global war: Oceania, Eurasia and Eastasia. The novel takes place in Oceania which is comprised of three social classes: The Elite (Inner Party) - 2% of the population, The Middle (Outer Party)- 13% of the population, and The Low (Proletarians or Proles)- the remaining 85% of the population.The Elite control every aspect of society through the elimination of personal freedoms, fear, and mind control, but according to the Elite this control is necessary to maintain the safety and security of the greater good. The Middle carries out the orders of the Elite. The Proles are viewed as mindless cattle that work, eat, sleep, and procreate. They're just a commodity to the Party.Even the language is controlled. It's continually being simplified. Words are being eradicated or concatenated into a language known as Newspeak. The idea is that if there is not a word for it, then it does not exist. Reading and expressing your own views (verbally or in writing) are outlawed. Individualism is not allowed.""To do anything that suggested a taste for solitude, even to go for a walk by yourself, was always slightly dangerous. There was a word for it in Newspeak: ownlife, it was called, meaning individualism and eccentricity.""The masses are under constant surveillance through telescreens, wiretapping and hidden cameras. The only time they have alone is when they are sleeping, and even then a word uttered against the Party could have one arrested by the Thought Police for a thoughtcrime.""BIG BROTHER IS WATCHING YOU.""The government of Oceania established four ministries to maintain control over the people. The names reflect the brainwashing methods of the Inner Party:1. Ministry of Truth (news)The Party controls the media and thereby controls the ""truth."" The past is continually being rewritten (fabrication, not truth) to reflect favorably on the Party, and any evidence to the contrary is eradicated.""He who controls the past controls the future. He who controls the present controls the past.""2. Ministry of Peace (war),Oceania is constantly at war (not at peace) with one of the other superpowers.  This endless war is a means to keep the people under control. The angst felt at the loss of their personal freedoms is directed, or rather misdirected, at one of the other superpowers. They are too busy preparing for or thinking about war to believe otherwise.""Heavy physical work, the care of the home and children, petty quarrels with neighbors, films, football, beer, and above all, gambling filled up the horizon of their minds. To keep them in control was not difficult.""3. Ministry of Plenty (economic affairs),Basic human needs like food and water are under the control of the Party. Food is scarce, not plenty. The Party employs self-preservation as a powerful influence over the masses.4. Ministry of Love (law and order)Psychological and physical torture (not love) is used to punish any acts of rebellion against the Party. The Ministry of Love is located in a building where there are no windows. It's continually bathed in light. Since one cannot distinguish between night and day, the passage of time is unknown. The following sentence appears early in the novel and gives the reader a feeling of hope, but by the end it is evident that it refers to something completely different.""We shall meet in the place where this is no darkness.""The protagonist, Winston Smith, is a member of the Outer Party who works for the Ministry of Truth where he rewrites history to cast a favorable light on the Party. He seems to be the everyman hero at the beginning of the novel. There is nothing unique about him other than his desire to write down his own thoughts, to dream of a better life, but in this Orwellian society those desires are quite extraordinary. He purchases a journal in secret and writes his thoughts in it with his back to the telescreen. That act alone could have him arrested by the Thought Police, but he goes further with the declaration of ""DOWN WITH BIG BROTHER"" at great personal risk of being ""vaporized"" (eradicated from existence). Readers will immediately root for him.Orwell created a world so believable and prophetic that it is actually quite frightening. Don't think so? We only have to look at the recent past, the era just prior to the time the book was written, for an answer. It happened during the Third Reich with the rise of Hitler. An entire nation was brainwashed through propaganda into dehumanizing the Jewish population, and we know the unspeakable atrocities that followed. Who says it cannot happen again?This novel is complex and thought-provoking. Although it was written in 1948 about the future, and 1984 has long since passed, it is still relevant today. I believe the author intended it to be a warning of what could be. It will leave you with a feeling of deep concern about the danger inherent in giving up too much personal freedom. I highly recommend this book."
"This is a really good book,a little scary in my opinion.I can't believe that this book was published in 1949 because everything is true in it.Makes me wonder what is to come,pretty sure not something good."
"Comparisons between Orwell's NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR and Huxley's BRAVE NEW WORLD are so common in literary circles that they have become somewhat of a joke.  Especially when you consider that neither of these books was the first in the genre; while Huxley predated Orwell by seventeen years, somehow Zamyatin's WE, written a decade before BNW, often gets left out of the discussion (in fact it has been some time since I read WE, and I read two different translations, so I would need to tackle it again to review it properly).  And there are other novels in this genre that are worthy of consideration, such as Levin's THIS PERFECT DAY and Bradbury's FAHRENHEIT 451.  But at the end of the day, when it comes to the ultimate dystopia, it is Orwell's NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR that emerges as the absolute expression of the genre in all its nightmarish vividness.London, 1984 (Or is it? Nothing is certain in this book).  We are introduced to Winston Smith, a clerical worker for the ruling body, an entity known only as ""the Party"" and represented by posters of a Stalin-like figure known only as ""Big Brother"" and the slogan ""Big Brother Is Watching You.""  Which is literally true:  everyone's apartment is equipped with a two-way television (""telescreen"") that sees and hears absolutely everything, from eating to sleep to sex, and which can be turned down but not off.Winston's job sums up the Party pretty well:  it is his task to process changes to newspapers, history books, magazines, any form of literature so that the present will match up with the past.  In short, it is his function to completely obliterate history on a daily basis.  The world is divided into three primary ""provinces:""  Oceania (in which London is located and which oddly appears to include the United States), Eurasia, and Eastasia.  There is always a war going on between Oceania and one of the other two, but it is subject to change on a dime, and when it does, Winston and his team must scramble to change all records to make them state that Oceania has ALWAYS been at war with whichever one happens to be the enemy at the moment.It is instructive that Winston performs his duties at a place called the Ministry of Truth, which is in fact dedicated to falsification of everything from history books to television shows.  There are two other Ministries:  The Ministry of Peace, which is concerned with war, and the Ministry of Love, which is concerned with horrors that I will not reveal here.Speaking of love, this is where comparisons with Huxley actually have some merit.  Both novels have removed all meaning from the sex act.  But Huxley does it by making promiscuity the order of the day and making any feelings deeper than the basic tactile sexual sensations deviant, unnatural, and anti-social.  Orwell does it by making sex a crime except for the necessity of procreation and in his world pleasure for the woman is the unnatural thing.  Winston has a wife (who left him some time earlier), but the descriptions of their couplings are bone-chilling:  a dedicated Party member, his wife hated sex but insisted that they do it once a week to make a baby, calling it (God help us all) ""Our duty to the Party.""  Winston's relief at her departure is almost palpable even though we only hear about it as a past event.Slogans abound in Orwell's world.  The three primary ones are WAR IS PEACE, FREEDOM IS SLAVERY, and IGNORANCE IS STRENGTH, all of which eerily recall the words that greeted the prisoners arriving at Auschwitz:  ARBECHT MACHT FREI (literally ""Work Makes One Free"" but more accurately ""Freedom Through Work"").Orwell does not limit his inspirations to Nazi Germany, though:  I have already mentioned the resemblance between the mythical ""Big Brother"" and Josef Stalin; his characters address each other as ""comrade"" and there is mention made on more than one occasion of work camps that sound more like Siberia than WWII Germany.Orwell was an unremitting pessimist.  The plot of his novel is so simple it is almost predictable:  Winston is an unhappy member of the Party, and unhappy people sooner or later do something rebellious.  Winston rebels, with a young woman named Julia, and there follows a brief period where things appear to be hopeful, but eventually the hammer falls, and the ending is almost preordained.Which brings us to the one other valid comparison to Huxley; in BNW, London is a city so sterile you could probably eat off the floors.  NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR, on the other hand, is so grimy that you almost want to wash your hands after reading it.  The only other novel I can think of that presents the reader with such an unrelentingly gritty vision of the future is Harry Harrison's MAKE ROOM!  MAKE ROOM!, the inspiration for the film SOYLENT GREEN.There are a lot of futuristic dystopias out there, and they tend to share various features:  the genre is a narrow one, rather like horror and science fiction, and some crossover is inevitable.  But NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR stands out, somehow, above all the others; it has a grim resonance that is not only rather depressing but one gets the feeling that his vision is not in the least bit impossible and that we would do well to take care that we do not end up in Oceania."

"This volume is for people who are obsessively involved with Orwell's masterpiece ""1984"". To put it simply, this volume shows Orwell's handwritten original pages to the manuscript (including omissions) alongside corresponding pages that show the same information except in typed form so that the omissions may be clearly read. It shows the author's development in real-time, as he progressed, determining what he felt was appropriate for the final draft. You can clearly see Mr. Orwell changing  passages, adding (and omitting) certain details and trimming down (for effectiveness) a work that was to be one of the most influential literary dystopian warnings our world has yet seen. If you are a true fan of this novel (1984), The Facsimile will blow your mind. It is of a much larger size (nearly 11x17), is filled with insight, and will keep you reflective on a text you may have read and re-read a hundred times. The detailed photos on every other page of Orwell's handwritten copy show the intimacy that lay behind his every word. The typed translations give you insight into what details were just marginal enough for him to erase or adversely, add to. If you STUDY 1984, TEACH 1984, or OBSESS over 1984, you will NEVER get tired of this gem."

"I have read 1984 over a dozen times in my 53 years. There are very few books I have read that often, certainly Fahrenheit 451 and perhaps Animal Farm.  1984 is a book I need to read every now and then just to make sure I don't forget the warnings in it and to enable me to see how much of what Orwell warned us about has already come to pass.It's an important book. I don't use the term lightly. Masquerading as a science fiction novel we have a clear view of our time and what's awaiting us bleakly presented to us by a wise, clairvoyant man.I disagree with some reviewers who feel the book was inspired solely by totalitarian Russia.  The book was written in 1948 and well after Orwell's experience in Spain fighting with other idealists in the International Brigade but he put a lot of his Spanish experiences into 1984.  If you read Orwell's Homage to Catalonia you can see how he discovered that there is no real truth; what masquerades as truth can be changed at will and varies from place to place, from hour to hour.  Certain streets in Barcelona changed their alliances in the civil war from week to week and had no memory that there had ever been a change.  Orwell came to help the Spanish and ended up being on a wanted list because of the unorganised nature of civil war.His idealism was replaced with cynicism and a clear capacity to see through the smoke and mirrors and most importantly, a talent for sharing his wisdom with us.I sometimes fantasise about the result if George Orwell and Ray Bradbury had one day got together to write a book......"

Take a few minutes just to look at the language of the first couple of pages.  Orwell appeals to all of our senses to bring us into the story."

"I am glad I read this book after hearing about it all my life.On the upside Orwell created terms that have become part of our vocabulary (Big Brother, Double Think, Orwellian). The writer does not have the gift to keep you wanting to turn the page.  In the end you are glad the book has come to an end.I recently purchased four ""classics"". The others may be considered great because of their ideas contained or their timeliness.  But of the four only In Cold Blood doesn't need crutches.  Perhaps Capote is the only ""great writer"" of the four.  Orwell and Bradbury being idea men, and Kerouac being some adolescent fluke (a Miley Ray Cyrus of his literary time)."

"Update # 2It's been over a year now since I read 1984 and I can't get it out of my mind. I didn't like it much when I read it...I still don't like the outcome, but you have to admire any book that haunts you like this one does. Orwell's ability to make me think about this story so consistently for such a long period of time is a credit to his greatness. It has become the book I love to hate and for that it gets another star.UpdateSo I have had a month to consider this book. I find myself thinking about it a fair amount. I now think the point of this book was to make people become outraged at the story. To use this story as a way to incite people to fight against Government control. To not let things get close to becoming this way. Since it was written around the time of war, Orwell may have sensed that the Government might consider using the war as an excuse to tighten the reigns on the population. Anyhow, if a book keeps me thinking like this book has, it gets an extra star.Original ReviewTo put it bluntly, and probably much to the dismay of many, I did not like this book. It was monotonous for the first few chapters - which I think was probably the point. The rest was OK until I got to the end. I'm not sure what the author was trying to say. Perhaps ""Just give up, you can't beat the Government"" or ""Give up on striving for anything, it won't happen in the end"" or even ""Every person is so insignificant that they might as well end it all now"". One might think the Government itself paid the author to put that out to make a point. In the end, to me, it doesn't matter. I didn't like the message that I read in it."

"1) Plot (3 stars) - In a future where you're every move is watched for unorthodoxy, one man dares to question and in so doing learns the truth about his society.  But at what price?  It was a good plot, though at times it moved a bit slow, and in many parts it was told in lecture as opposed to character discovery or dialogue.2) Characters (3 stars) - Winston is the nervous lead, gingerly stepping into more and more truth and danger.  Julia is the rambunctious female interest who boldly yanks him forward.  The two leads were good vehicles to push the plot, but neither was particularly memorable.3) Theme (5 stars) - This is the classic exploration of life under a modern police state, of what happens when people's fears cause them to give up their freedoms, and how those in power will continue to manipulate those fears to retain power.  It successfully predicted Eastern Europe under the Soviet empire, Mao's Cultural Revolution, and modern day North Korea.  Some like to also hold it up as an example of where the US is heading, but I find that connection a bit more tenuous.  Certainly the technology now exists to create much of the surveillance and data manipulation apparatus described in the book, but in Western countries like the US that same technology has been democratized, spread into the hands of the many, a counterbalancing phenomenon that was not prognosticated nor explored in the book.4) Voice (3 stars) - The prose was fine, but I didn't mark any sentences as particularly poetic, beautiful, or insightful.  Also, I found certain sections to be a bit ""lecturey.""5) Setting (4 stars) - Orwell successfully transported me into the mood of this dystopia--the greyness, the shuffling hunchback people nervously checking over their shoulders, the hopelessness of being trapped under the thumb of Big Brother.6) Overall (4 stars) - I'd recommend 1984 for the exploration of the dangers of the police state and the dark feeling of dystopia, though I wished there was more to the plot and characters."
Every Student should read this classic. One of George Orwell's best works if not THE best. Something that seemed so impossible to happen when I read it as a teenager is now a fact of life...
"I highly recommend this book to anyone who values their personal freedom.  I first read this book in the early 1960's and did not think too much of it at the time.  I am a law abiding, responsible person who loves the USA and am not part of any conspiracy group or movement.The book was published in 1949 and was required reading for a college level Political Science course I took in the early 1960's.  Although we knew it was a work of fiction, our instructor likened it to life in a ""totalitarian communist or socialists"" country. The life described in the book was totally foreign to life in a free republic like the U.S. Now, fast-forward fifty years to current political realities of life in the U.S. and one must conclude that Orwell was a prophet of the Moses class. Were we told in 1960 that our government would one day own or control major U.S. industries such as; banking, mortgage, insurance, automotive, health care and energy we would think the person making such a claim was totally uninformed or in need of psychiatric care.  On top of outright ownership or control is the added influence exerted on private businesses by government rules and regulations and it becomes easy to see that ""1984"" is now more fact than fiction.The traditional ""free enterprise, capitalists"" system seems to have given way to the concept of ""redistribution of wealth"".  Even salaries paid within private corporations, in some instances, is controlled by government.As if that wasn't enough, within the past year, our trust in government has been further undermined by learning that government agencies trusted with our most private and sensitive personal information (think IRS) have punished people for their political views as well as shared private information with other governmental and private organizations in violation of established law and regulations.The most recent cause for a healthy skepticism about our government follows the disclosure that the National Security Agency has been collecting untold amounts of phone, email and other electronic data on the communications of law abiding citizens without warrants or justification.  This coupled with the GPS tracking system causes one to wonder; just how much surveillance is really necessary?Like Orwell's 1984, our government officially makes promises it does not or cannot keep.  What was once the truth, now by virtue of political correctness, becomes hate speech.  Religious thought is criticized and demeaned and is being forced from the public square.  Government redefines or excludes certain traditional words from public discourse.Although I encourage anyone who desires to know about our founding principles to read any number of good books by our founding fathers, I believe it would do us all good to read Orwell's 1984.  Although a work of fiction it unfortunately rings very true."

"Reading George Orwelll's 1984 in post Edward Snowden America is almost surreal. Perhaps Orwell foresaw that Britain would wield surveillance like an unrestrained weapon, with London boasting more CCTV cameras than any other city in Europe. But he couldn't have guessed that the degree of surveillance he imagined in his worst nightmares, when he wrote the book, would be so easily surpassed by an out-of-control NSA in the United States. Nor that for the sake of convenience or a delusional sense of security, people would be so willing to reveal their every last thought to Big Brother simply by an appeal to their egos. Today's Big Brother need not to worry about formerly-illegal eavesdropping to capture ""thought criminals"" or flag their Google searches. Or torture without the threat of prosecution or sanction. He just needs to read their tweets. If he has the patience."

"A powerful novel written in 1949 about one man's view and experience from inside a dystopian society where the government spies on its citizens continuously to stifle dissent, maintains the citizens in a state of constant fear by fabricating enemies and wars and tortures it's citizens when they're found to have incorrect thinking.  George Orwell's haunting examination of the natural inclination to resist regimented control by all-powerful authority figures, the desire to experience closeness and intimacy with another human (an act forbidden in this controlled society) with the recognition of the inevitable discovery and destruction by the state is a disturbing look at the inside of a totalitarian society.  Unfortunately, it appears that this is the direction in which Western, so-called democratic and free countries are heading.  The real eye-opener is the admission by the state rulers (and torturers) that perpetuating this living hell of a society was solely to accumulate and maintain ever-increasing amounts of power.  This is a clear-eyed view of the psychopaths (like Stalin, Hitler and, quite possibly, our current governments in the West) who gain power and manipulate the system in every way possible to strive for ultimate power, with no recognition of the cost to other's lives.  This book should be on everyone's reading list as a cautionary tale about how democratic countries can be hijacked by psychopathic rulers for their own selfish accumulation of power and how fragile freedom and liberty is."
"This is one of my favorite novels/essays. The characters are not extremely interesting or well developed, but the subject matter is relevant and should be studied."
"Much of NSA's previous work has been criticized as disingenuous, bland and excessively brief, but the agency seems to have completely reinvented itself in its latest work, ""1984: Blueprint for a Stronger Democracy."" The book details a utopian society in which a political dissident is transformed by a series of interactions with his benevolent totalitarian government and in the end comes to see that he does, in fact, love the state's omnipresent dictator, known as Big Brother.I have no doubt that we are making a great deal of progress in making this vision a reality, as government surveillance grows ever more powerful. Political dissidents might finally start to keep their views to themselves if they realize that their online activity is being monitored, and that inappropriate use of the internet will result in a visit from the government. But reading NSA's latest work left me deeply troubled, for it is clear that American citizens still have excessive freedom to communicate with each other. I can only hope that Edward Snowden's recent revelations about the scope of NSA's surveillance is just the tip of the iceberg.There are few other classics so relevant today as this one.10/10 would read again."

"1984 is a must read, it is a book that portrays utopian society like no other. The story is about a totalitarian society located in Britian and surrounding countries that shows how a society can strive by monitoring everyone's personal space. There is always a news screen that watches over the people, cameras that can find anything and everything that happens inside their country. The struggle to become ""normal"" or what the main character believes is normal is strong, they try to escape their fate of being bounded by the highest class, ""Big Brother"". The development of this totalitarian society shows Winston, the main character, being brainwashed from missing words to losing memories.This book surrounds the idea that our society of communism is similar to such a community. Stalin's Russia, China's Mao Ze Dong, and Korea's Kim Jong Il can all be seen as this society's leader. With present day leaders, we find that this novel is trying to explain that we cannot have everyone being controlled, there must be freedom for the people to at least breath differently. As the story progresses, we find that their society succeeded, but as a result they lose intelligence. For example, they lose words such as ""bad"" and replaced it with ""doubleplusungood"". This small vocab is used to not have the people rebel, but it is simply not the answer to our current society."
"George Orwell's ""1984"" is one of those classics from the late 1940s that many may have vaguely heard of but not familiar with. Many may not be aware of  the origin of some common phases from the book that are widely used, e.g. ""double-think"", ""big brother"", ""newspeak"".  Not sure that it's still part of  most high school education curricula (where I read it in the late 1960s). I bought a copy (along with Orwell's ""Animal Farm"") for one of my post-college daughters who attended what is consider a superior high school, but she has not read either of them then. See my May 2014 review of ""Animal Farm"" on its Amazon page. (http://www.amazon.com/review/R3G6I5FLIJ4UKC/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm)The relatively short novel should be read by all as part of one's education, and if not in entirety, the appendix section give a few pages explanation of ""Newspeak"" language that should resonate with the use of similar on occasion by present day governments (including our own), corporations, etc. Newspeak can use words and phraseology that actually mean the opposite of  their traditional meanings. This book (along with ""Animal Farm"") is definitely worth a few hours of reading.The story is about one man's life in a totalitarian British society that's a thinly disguised copy (but on steriods) of Stalin's Soviet Union. Many of societal features described will be familiar to anyone who'd read objective first-hand accounts, or lived in places like the old Soviet Union, Mao's China, North Korea, and some other present day non-democratic countries. Some of the described governmental capabilities and controls are frighteningly modern-day as our present technology allows governments to more easily deployed systems like wide-spread video monitoring, communications monitoring, media/information control, etc.As I got older, the novel is a part my education that gives more appreciation of the wisdom of our country's founders in the way they wrote the Constitution, because they did not trust governments (really any people in power) in general to always have the public interests in mind. They set up the  US government to be split into 3 different independent parts to provide some checks against each other, there's a Bill of Rights that lists some fundamental things regarding what the government can and can not do, and the Constitution is, on a basic level, a limited list of enumerated federal powers, with all other powers (stated or unstated) reserved to the states and/or the people. Even having all that, we always need to be on guard for potential degradation of what the Constitution intends, e.g. enabling free politcal speech at any time, protection against unreasonable searches, protection against arbitrary government actions (legal right to contest actions before implementation), etc."

"***SPOILERS AHEAD***I have read BRAVE NEW WORLD (by Aldous Huxley), but I had never read 1984 (somehow missed that one through high school and college), so I recently decided to read it.  I loved it until about 2/3 of the way through. Orwell is obviously a talented writer.  However, 2/3 into it, the plot nose-dived into hopelessness.  Apparently, Orwell did not believe in the triumph of the human spirit---far from it. Look, I realize that not all novels will have a Jane Austen ending, but the main objection I have to this novel is that I don't buy Orwell's premise of the possibility of an all-powerful, almost all-knowing government existing and being tolerated by the majority.  Believe me, I'm no Pollyanna, and I believe there are enough ""useful idiots"" in our society to ruin it . . . just not to the extent that Orwell portrays in 1984.  Big Brother's tactics are too obvious to be tolerated by the majority.  We never see how the society got to the point where people were somehow willing to be not only spied upon 24/7, take orders from the telescreen, allow children to be in a Spy League and report their own parents, and blithely accept PUBLIC revisions of history with not a murmur. Perhaps if that had somehow been explained, I would have found it more plausible.  I realize that governments often try many of these tactics with some success, but not without some sort of resistance from the public---whether the public in that country or in another. I simply don't believe that there would be such wholesale buy-in when the motivator is fear.  In this novel, Orwell makes Big Brother almost a god that cannot be beat.  If the vision he has is that it is utterly hopeless, what's the point of writing novel?  If Orwell intended it as a ""warning"" against allowing totalitarian regimes into power, he should have included some idea of how one gets from A (freedom) to Z (complete, utter slavery to the government); to me, that's the missing piece of this novel.I am much more inclined to believe Huxley's dystopian vision is the more plausible one. In BRAVE NEW WORLD, people conform because they are so steeped in vacuous entertainments (e.g., casual sex, movies based completely on feeling, drugs, etc.) that they allow themselves to be ruled.  That's a subtler form of slavery where the mind of the majority is captured by the ruling powers because the majority willingly allows their minds to be captured.  That is much more plausible, to me, than Orwell's dystopian prediction in 1984.  Also, Huxley's vision still takes into account (more realistically, I might add) that human beings will still ultimately be human beings.  Orwell's novel does not.Ultimately, though, both novels (and, indeed, all dystopian visions like them that I've read) never take God into account.  They portray societies where humankind has the ultimate power.  Thus, for Christian readers, such novels may not be as scary as for others because we know that ultimately, God is in control, not human beings.I'm glad I read the novel, but it is not one that I will re-read."

The fact that it can easily be tied into today's society make it that much better."

"Here's something you don't see everyday: a more or less negative review of 1984.  Let me be clear; it's not a bad book.  But once you consider how much people tend to hype this up, and constantly refer to it as an example of what would happen if we let fear force us to give up our civil liberties, this book is over the top.  Seriously, the dictatorship in this book makes the Nazis look like the Peace Corp.  Fake wars, mind control, and cameras in your toilet are some of the things citizens in 1984 have come accept as normal.  Seem far fetched? It is.If you can look past the in-your-face political agenda of this book, then the story is OK.  The protagonist is not exactly an interesting or personable character, and while intentional, makes the book more work than pleasure.  If you want to read it for the story, fine, but don't ever take this as a serious look into society.  Do yourself a favor and read Orwell's Animal Farm instead, which is essentially a book about the same concept except crafted much more artfully.  If you must read something about a utopia with an oppressive society, get Brave New World by Aldous Huxley.  Much better story overall in my opinion, with a more subtle and relevant political message."

"This is story of the past, but when it was written it was the story of the future.Orwell sets the scene in which the goverment of 1984, led by Big Brother (much like the governments of today), has become adept at saying white when it really means black, and black when it really means white. "This book is great and I would recommend reading it in conjuction with WE,Brave New World, and maybe even Animal Farm. Huxley wrote his book in 1932 and Orwell's book ""1984"" (that was written in 1949) carried the genre to greater heights, which is why ""1984"" is the most known of the mentioned 3 books.In ""Brave New World,"" Huxley successfully predicts the future of genetic engineering. There are no parents or families, death no longer elicits emotional reactions, and men and women are expected to have with innumerable sexual partners. The society is genetically altered into class divisions known as Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, and Epsilon. Alphas are the most intelligent, have the most important jobs, and have the most free will. In contrast, Epsilon's are the least intelligent, have the worst jobs, and have the least amount of free will. The society displayed is one that needs entertainment to be happy and live for a drug known as soma, which removes all pain and makes them ""happy.""""WE"" is most like 1984 in the prediction of how the future will be.  They both see people losing their personal identity and becoming just a number.  ""WE"" is written in first person, as a journal entry of D-503's life. He lives in a city that is surrounded by a green wall and in a society where people have no names, just numbers, and follow a strict schedule for work, sleep, leisure activities, and even sex. The journal explains who he is, his daily schedule, and eventually gives a detailed account of his inner thoughts as he wrestles with the idea that all is not as it appears with the world. All this begins when he meets I-303 for the first time. (That is all I will say - no spoilers here.)""1984"" centers around one character, Winston.  Winston is living in the UK which is under the control of BIG BROTHER.  In this society, one must do, think, say, and appear as if they believe and follow what BIG BROTHER wants.  Cameras are everywhere, even inside houses.  Kids report parents for deviating from what the ""Party"" wants.  Fellow citizens look for small changes in your face or activities that might be evidence of ""thought crimes.""  In this society, one must only think it to be convicted of the crime.  As Winston lives his life, he hides a secret from everyone hoping one day to find others who do not agree with the doings of the ""Party.""  He meets a woman, and they embark on a journey to find the underground resistance that is against BIG BROTHER.  Their lives will be forever changed because of this decision.I think that all of these works are relevant today to read or re-read.  I would recommend these books to anyone.  Happy reading!"

"Whatever one might say about the merits of the Orwellian worldview of the totalitarian state (which eerily  resembles in modern liberal state in quite a number of ways), I don't think many would deny that the book is extremely well written. It's very engaging, very creative, prophetic (as many have pointed out - NSA, anyone?) and, at the conclusion of every chapter, left me with a desire to uncover what happens next.But I think it's precisely the Orwellian critique of the totalitarian state that makes the book so important. This book is a treatise on precisely what modern liberalism has to wrestle with because it begs over and again the questions of what might finally happen when you've stripped language of its value, invaded personal liberties and property rights for the sake of safety, turn health-care over to the highest governmental controls, robbed parents of the responsibility to provide an education for their children, eliminate or oppress all rival philosophies to the state (whether it be the Church, charities, public debate, or the villainizing of other countries), etc. -- in other words, the dangers of the liberal political philosophy, in both its ideals and habits, taken to the logical conclusion. And even if one were to say that this is not the only conclusion possible for the liberal state by suggesting that this happens to be the worst of the possible outcomes, it is still no trivial matter to scrutinize the risk of taking political roads which may bring us to this destination.Nineteen Eighty-Four is a book well worth your time to read, probably, even more valuable to study, and certainly an addition to my list of books to read every year."

"That George Orwell really knows how to scare the pants off a person.  He wrote about angered animals revolting and taking over a farm, and now it's an all-encompassing, all-powerful government that controls every facet of its constituents' lives, right down to their very thoughts.1984 was primarily written during the years 1947 and 1948 and was published in June of 1949.  By the year 1989, Orwell's novel had been translated into 65 different languages, more than any other English-language novel at that time.  Throughout it's entire publication history it has been either banned or legally challenged somewhere in the world.  In 2005, Time magazine listed it in its ""100 best English-language novels from 1923-2005.""  It was also listed at number 6 in the ""Modern Library 100 Best Novels.""1984 follows the life of Winston Smith as he struggles to conform.  We get a first-hand look at the fear and distrust that rules his every thought and action.  Reading 1984 will definitely help you to appreciate your own situation, no matter how bad it may seem.  And if you're unclear on just exactly what a dystopian novel is, this is it.  This is the book that defines the genre.Frank Muller is one of my very favorite audiobook narrators, and a perfect fit for 1984.  His grit and solemnity serve to augment the funerary feel of the audiobook.  Muller has been a stage and television actor, but is most famous for his audiobook narration having narrated hundreds of novels.  He died in 2008 after many years of complications from a motorcycle accident in 2001.I think everyone should read 1984 at least once, and that time you were forced to read it in school doesn't count.  This is a good reminder of how things might have been, if history had turned out just a little bit different.  And any audiobook narrated by Frank Muller is worth a listen."

"I am on a kick of re-reading books that changed the way I see the world when I was younger, books like Atlas Shrugged, Brave New World and 1984 -- they're all pretty heavy-handed.  To be sure, Atlas Shrugged is the worst if for no other reason than it is painfully long.  But all make a sort of attempt to build a plot and sooner or later digress into some sort of manifesto.  In the case of 1984, the main character finds a banned book from the leader of the resistance and several chapters of the real book are from the fictional book.One thing I do recall from learning to write in high school and college is: show, don't tell.  All of these books, in particular 1984 are pretty thin using the fiction and plot as a thin veneer over their views.  In each case, they fall into long monologs or sections that suggest the author is bored of trying to present their dystopian worlds as a canvas.  I would have gotten a C+ at best for any of these had I turned them in.What's interesting to me why these books are so different now.  In the case of 1984, I read it when that year was still in the future and it wasn't quite so dated.  But I was also 16 and perhaps not as critical a reader as I am now.  Or perhaps the end of the cold war and all that has happened since has just changed the way the world is.  Or maybe in my youth or ignorance I was more tolerant of these black-and-white views of the world.So in a way, it's worth re-reading as a way of reflection on ones past.  Perhaps I won't be as disappointed as I delve back into the three books that made me appreciate literature: The Sun Also Rises, Crime and Punishment, and The Red and the Black."

"A little background information: George Orwell wrote this novel as a warning to future Americans about what could happen if the government continued to run the way it was.1984 takes place in the former England, where the protagonist Winston lives. Winston was born before the Party came into power, but he is unable to remember anything about his childhood, his parents, or life before the 'Revolution.'Throughout the story, Winston becomes increasingly dissatisfied with his life and begins to rebel. This process speeds up when he meets a young girl at the Ministry named Julia (he had formerly thought that she was a member of the Thought Police who was after him because he was rebelling). They have a love affair (which is illegal) and are caught after just a few months.After months of torture, Winston is finally released. At the end of the book, he accepts and even comes to love the ideals of a society which he had once despised.This story leaves the reader with a sense of hopelessness because no matter what Winston does, he is incapable of defeating the Party. However, many comparisons can be made to today's world. This story was very well written and also contained many interesting, futuristic aspects.While a depressing story, I enjoyed reading it. I would recommend it to anyone who has enjoyed other dystopian novels (The Lord of the Flies, Fahrenheit 451, etc.)"

"1984There has been a mini-boom in the sales of Orwell's prophetic book.Some vocabulary from the book '1984' has already entered our speech: Big Brother, Doublespeak, etc.And no wonder, since much of the surveillance technology that Orwell wrote about is already with us.""Trust me, I'm from the government,"" is a mild form of ""Big Brother's"" pitch.Of course Big Brother knows all your day to day problems: his agents watch and listen to everything. TV cameras are everywhere and your communications are intercepted.The good and bad things in life are given new names. Good = bad & Bad = goodSome speech becomes PC (politically correct) and other speech is deleted from the language.Orwell was certainly concerned about fascism and communism. But he was also concerned with tendencies in democracies towards suppression of minorities and their aspirations.Orwell was not the first or the last political writer who foresaw oppression by majority rule. Alexis de Tocqueville commented on the tendency in America to conformism and to ""majoritarianism"", intolerance for other cultural traditions.Virtually all political commentators saw the threat of ""bolshevism"", which was the Russian term for the ""majority"" party in the legislative assembly. Under the Communists, ""Bolshevism"" stood for the ""dictatorship of the majority"", another term for the dictatorship of the proletariat. Majoritarianism. Totalitarian democracy.Both De Tocqueville and Orwell saw the risk of ""democracy"" becoming ""majoritarianism"" and then evolving into ""totalitarian democracy"".The framers of the US Bill of Rights saw this danger too and added to the Constitution the safeguards that once served to make America a beacon for the rest of the world.1984 is a book worth reading because it shows how everything can go wrong when people place too much trust in Big Brother.Terrorism? Big Brother says that's what the bad guys do. We bomb people in far off places to make the world safe for democracy. The old and sick and women and children die when we sent in the drones. They just happened to sit down to dinner in the wrong place at the wrong time. Some ""collateral damage"" happens.Spying? Big Brother says we spy only on foreign bad guys who contact local bad guys. If you are innocent, you don't have to worry.Orwell knew his history.When they came for the gypsies, I didn't protest because I'm not a gypsy.When they came for the anarchists, I didn't protest because I'm not an anarchist.When they came for the Jews, I didn't protest because I'm not a Jew.But when they came for me, I saw there was nobody left in my street to protest. So they took me away.1984 is a book for our times because it shows us that the price of liberty is eternal vigilance.We can see in this book how important it is to control technology to prevent its abuse. Otherwise elites in modern democracies  will subvert constitutional safeguards by stealth, by smooth promises, and by offering security from outside threats both real and invented."
"With the way many are concerned about how much our government is involved in our daily lives, this is a great read. Amazing that it was written so long ago. If you haven't read this book, I highly recommend it."
I cannot say how much I love this book. I was expecting a happy ending but was actually pleasantly surprised it ended the way it did. Must read for everyone.
"With the latest revelations of NSA intelligence-gathering techniques, a friend of mine suggested that I pick up this book.  What shocked me was the accuracy with which Orwell predicted government intrusion into daily life....in 1948!!!  Orwell imagines people sitting in front of screens every day that monitor their daily activity.  He sees the ability to track and listen-in on people on the move as another tool in the pocket of the government.  Through our smartphones and computers, the government today has intruded into almost every aspect of our lives.There are some further parallels can be drawn as well.  Orwell saw one factor in the political decline as the loss of ""external reality,"" namely that reality is objective and observable.  Such a concrete philosophical notion of reality has been replaced by the current postmodern subjective reality where 2+2 *can* equal 5, if that's what I think it equals.  In today's society where there is no sin or goodness but in what you determine to be such, there is but one small step towards an Orwellian society.  If the locus of what determines reality shifts from the person to the state.  And perhaps much of this has already happened behind our backs.  Because most of us have lost our notions of objective external reality through the public education system of our nation.And then there's the issue of history.  In an age where we're moving more and more towards reliance on cloud-based electronic mediums, erasure of history is truly only a keystroke away.  Oral traditions and histories have been exchanged for written ones.  Written ones have been exchanged for electronic ones.  And the end result is that most in our society knows less about history than ever.  Contrary to Emerson and other writers and thinkers who have seen history (and living in light of history) as weak or sub-human, Orwell sees history in its rightful primacy.  If we don't understand the past, we can't possibly understand the present.  The richness of history leads us to the greatness of religion, the beauty of art, and the heights of science.  Ignoring history leads only to self-destruction, enslavement, and loss of beauty.I would suggest pairing this read with Huxley's equally dystopian ""A Brave New World"" for maximum effect.  Readers should be advised that there are several depictions of sex and torture in some sections of this book.  The literary and historical significance of the work, however, makes it worth reading for the discerning adult.Let me close this review by saying that this book doesn't leave me as doom and gloom as I suppose it has left many other readers.  While I believe that man is capable of great evil like that portrayed in the book, I believe that things are not meant to be the way they are.  In spite of our notions of a subjective reality, the effects of self-serving politicians, poverty, famine, war, greed and so on strike us all as wrong because they really are fundamentally wrong.  We long for wrongs to be made right and for an objective, external reality that we can hang on to.  And nothing can take that feeling out of us.  Even if someone could use our deepest fears against us, we still cannot repress that testimony.  And it is because I know that the world is broken (as Orwell warns), I know it can be fixed."
"Loved it when I read it as a rebellious teen and now that we are actually LIVING 1984, it is a reminder of simpler times. I picked this up after I read an article that stated sales of this book had risen dramatically in recent weeks, i was on sale for $0.99 so a bargain anyway. Others have said it better, but if the American government scares you now, just wait until you read this."
"This is an extremely difficult novel to review. As a book of ideas, it is spectacular in the way it addresses the fears of oppression in a totalitarian society, which are both prophetic and yet timeless in the way it could be talking about the world any time after the mid twentieth century to our current times and beyond. As evidence of the timelessness of Orwell's creative dystopia, words and phrases coined in the imaginary world of Ingsoc (English Socialism) like Newspeak, doublethink, and the concept of Big Brother is still used today to shape our discourse about social and political realities today.However, as a narrative, I felt that the storyline was weighed down (rather ironically I thought) by the very pedantic way the issues Orwell sought to discuss were presented. In many ways, while the dangers of propaganda and historical revisions, and the loss of individualism and freedom were rather convincingly presented, the relentlessness of the message in the narrative became a kind of counter-propaganda of its own. For example, for the first part of the novel, Orwell presents Winston Smith, an everyday employee of the misnomered Ministry of Truth, whose job as editor was to flush old news that contradicted the current message the Party wanted to propagate, down the memory hole. The reader becomes aware of Winston's inherent dissent, 'thoughtcrime' and his illicit relationship with a fellow comrade that begins to signal his rebellion against the Party, and allegiance towards the revolutionary Brotherhood. However, for some reason, Orwell did not think it adequate enough to push the message across, and the action is brought to a standstill in Part 2 where Winston reads whole chunks from a counter-authoritarian manual of sorts, effectively subjecting the reader to an overstatement of all that is wrong with the authoritarian society. No doubt relevant and brilliant in the way the ideas were presented, it became a little underwhelming and repetitive.As a landmark novel on dystopian fiction, I can understand the clout it has in the literary milieu, as well as its powerful influence on other works after its publication, even though personally, I found it too heavy and ponderous for me."
"It will be obvious that many stories and myths have risen from the pages of this book... and what's worse, many of its pages contain visions that stare us in the face daily. Is not the iPad I'm writing this review on, a *perfect* implementation of a mobile telescreen, with its forward facing camera? Is the country of North Korea much different in policy than Oceania?This work of fiction could just as easily be a docu-drama based on the world we live in... I have no idea how it took me until 32 years of age to read it. This should be required in high school readingMust read."

But if one could find a place away from the screens, one was safe from Big Brother. Today Big Brother no longer has to watch us. Instead every time we turn on a computer, every time we carry a cellphone, every time we use a credit card, every time we pay our bills, every time we mail a letter, every time we write a check, some private company collects and stores that information. Instead of tacking 350 million American and getting warrants, Big Brother has only to access a dozen or so companies to get anything on anybody they need.And just to make sure no one falls through the cracks, Big Brother has given free cellphones and SNAP cards so even the poor can be tracked. Welcome to life in the goldfish bowl."

"We've all heard of ""1984"", or at least, the term ""Orwellian"" (interesting note: George Orwell was his pen name). I always thought of it as some sort of dystopian, apocalyptic and futuristic take about our future, which is a bleak one with ""big brother"" always watching and freedom being an illusion. One of the things that astounds me the most is that Orwell wrote this so long ago, yet it still resonates strongly. Even the technology he talks about seems very similar to what we have now. "The novel 1984, written in 1948 by George Orwell, was Orwell's most influential novel. 1984 follows Winston Smith, a lower-level Party member, along his quest to gain the actual truth and ideally freedom. Before the novel 1984, Orwell was mainly known for his allegorical novel Animal Farm. These two novels, 1984 and Animal Farm sold more copies than any other two novels from a single author in the 20th century. 1984 is a novel that depicts the horrors of a totalitarian government and society. He wrote the novel at the beginning of the spread of Communist and totalitarian governments. This was a key issue in society and a main source of inspiration for Orwell, who was obsessed with social injustice, and warning of the dangers of totalitarianism. 1984 gives Orwell's description or warning of totalitarian regimes is so intense that it includes enough detail and pessimism to make even idealistic supporters of Communism and Socialism to think twice.In 1984 the Earth has been separated into three separate super-states, Eastasia, Eurasia, and the state in which the novel takes place, Oceania. Oceania, the main setting, consists of modern day Great Britain and modern day United States. The totalitarian regime is under an entity call ""Big Brother"" and the ""Party."" In Oceania English is still the common language. However, ""Big Brother"" is transforming English into a new language called ""Newspeak."" ""Newspeak"" is a language based on removing any thoughts against ""Big Brother"" or any individual thought.The plot of the novel is not able to be briefly summarized and still do it justice. 1984 is not a novel with a story; it is a novel with a warning. Orwell beautifully composes a warning against totalitarianism and politically apathy, but in the focus of Winston Smith, a small insignificant Party member. Orwell creates a story that intertwines both the political and economic structure of Oceania along with Winston's quest for knowledge and freedom.Orwell's novel's enduring impression with 1984 is not in the description of the political or economic structure of Oceania, but with the dull minuet details of the story. The dreariness of life under a totalitarian regime is the main issue Orwell addresses silently. He creates a lifeless society that would strike fear in anyone in support of a totalitarian government.  Orwell connects the situation in Oceania to the real world by including principles such as ""doublethink"" that can be found in our society today. ""Doublethink"" principles are dominant in society. Principles such as people must ""fit into social norms"" but also be an ""individual,"" follow your dreams, but you must find a secure job, and even affirmative action are all examples of ""doublethink."" Affirmative action is a perfect example of ""doublethink"" in our society. It is used in hopes of ending discrimination by practicing it. To require a certain number of minorities attend school or are employed in a workplace is creating discrimination against non-minorities. This only continues the cycle of discrimination, and thus society supports something it says it is clearly opposed to.  This is how 1984 strikes home and how Orwell creates his timeless warning to society.George Orwell's 1984 was written in 1948 as a warning against the totalitarianism rising in the post-war political climate, but the warning is a timeless one. The novel is brilliantly written and tells a crucially important message to society. It is a must read story, if not for the plot for the message."
Even written in 1954 becomes more pertinent every day! I have loved the work of Orwell from when I was a teenager in 1984 and his concerns and fears are as real today as ever.
"The dystopia portrayed in 1984 is thoroughly disquieting. There is no redemption. In the words of the book's main antagonist, ""If you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face--forever."" Yet it is not only the structure of the Ingsoc society, which strips people of sanity and humanness, that so terrifies, but also a peek provided by the author into the very mind of darkness - the cold, confident logic of evil so absolute that it makes Dostoyevsky's Grand Inquisitor seem naïvely altruistic by comparison.Nineteen eighty four is clearly a warning. But I suspect that it might be read simplistically only as a warning against a narrowly defined political ideology. Orwell's own words, written in 1946 (""Why I Write""), are revealing: ""Every line of serious work that I have written since 1936 has been written, directly or indirectly, against totalitarianism and for democratic socialism, as I understand it."" Is Orwell then simultaneously for socialism and against it? After all, the very word Ingsoc is a shortening of ""English Socialism"". The book itself offers a clarification of the relationship between the etymology and meaning of Ingsoc: ""Thus, the Party rejects and vilifies every principle for which the Socialist movement originally stood, and it chooses to do this in the name of Socialism.""It is helpful to remember that a major theme in the book is the Party's deliberate perversion of language and the twisting of words into their diametric opposites. For example, the Ministry of Peace is concerned with war, the Ministry of Truth with deceit, and the Ministry of Love with torture. Thus, a movement concerned originally with equality has morphed horribly into a system of permanent, institutionalized inequality.Then, instead of regarding 1984 as merely another denunciation of Stalinism and Nazism, I think it is much more accurate to think of it as a sober warning against any assault on individual liberty, regardless of whether the attack comes under the banner of collectivism, patriotism, socialism, capitalism, or religion - a message that has by no means lost its relevance in the world today."
